(1)  Keep true and correct records of all sales, shipments or deliveries of such alcoholic beverages to any retail dealer in the unincorporated area of the county, such records to be kept for a period of one year for malt beverages and fermented wine and to be made available upon request to any duly authorized representative of the county. 
(2)  Collect from each such retail dealer in the unincorporated area of the county at the time of delivery of the malt beverages and fermented wine the amount of tax due under the terms of this section and to hold such amount in trust for the county until such amount is remitted to the county as provided in this section. 
(3)  Except as provided in O.C.G.A. § 3-5-81 or other applicable state law, on or before the 20th day of each calendar month make a verified and comprehensive report to the county finance office, which shall correctly show all sales and deliveries of malt beverages and fermented wine to or for retail dealers in the unincorporated area of the county for the month immediately preceding such report. Such report shall show the name and address of each retail dealer, the quantities delivered to each retail dealer, the amount collected under the terms of this section, and such other information as may be called for by the county. This report shall be accompanied by remittance to the county for all taxes collected or due as shown on the report. 
(d)  Noncompliance by wholesale dealer or distributor. If any wholesaler dealer or distributor fails or refuses to make the report provided for in this section, the county shall notify the party in writing; and if the reports are not made and the taxes remitted within five days from the date of notice, the county may revoke the wholesale dealer's or distributor's license. In addition, such a wholesaler shall pay a late payment charge of ten percent per month for each month of delinquency together with interest on the total amount due (including late payment fee) equal to one percent per month. 
(e)  Unlawful retail sales. It shall be a violation of this section for any person to sell at retail within the limits of the unincorporated area of the county any malt beverages or fermented wine on which the taxes provided for in this section have not been paid. This section shall also apply to farm wineries. 
(f)  Unlawful deliveries. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any wholesale dealer or distributor to deliver any malt beverages or fermented wine to any retail dealer in the unincorporated area of the county without collecting the taxes provided for in this section at the time of delivery. 
(g)  Posting of bonds. Each wholesaler dealer or distributor who sells malt beverages or fermented wines to retail dealers in the unincorporated area of the county shall post a bond in the sum of $10,000.00 as a condition that such dealer or distributor shall comply with every provision and make payment of any sums due under this section. If the wholesaler's license shall be revoked for cause, the bond shall be forfeited and paid to the county. 
(h)  Violations and penalties. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section, or who shall assist any retail dealer in malt beverages or fermented wines in the county to evade or avoid the payment of the taxes provided for in this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9 and shall also be subject to having his license revoked. 
(i)  Farm wineries. Wines sold at retail by a farm winery shall have levied thereon the excise tax that applies to wholesalers. Farm wineries shall prepare and keep accurate records as to what is sold at retail and what is sold at wholesale for a period of one year. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
State Law reference— Nudity and related acts on premises, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-41; employee solicitation of patrons for drinks on premises, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-42; display of prices of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-26; levy of tax on sale of distilled spirits by the package authorized, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-80; sale of distilled spirits by the drink, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-90 et seq.; imposition of excise tax on malt beverages required, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-80; authorization to levy tax on wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-60. 
Sec. 6-9. - License required for manufacture, sale. 
(a)  No alcoholic beverages shall be manufactured or sold at wholesale except under a wholesale wine and malt beverage license granted by the board of commissioners. 
(b)  No alcoholic beverages shall be sold by the package for off-premises consumption except wine and malt beverages under a retail alcoholic wine and malt beverage package sales license granted by the board of commissioners. 
(c)  No alcoholic beverages shall be sold at retail for consumption on-premises except under an alcoholic beverage pouring license granted by the board of commissioners. 
(d)  A farm winery is required to obtain a license as provided in this chapter for the manufacture of wine. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
State Law reference— Local permit or license required for wholesale or retail sales of alcoholic beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2(a). 
Sec. 6-10. - Application, filing; form; contents. 
(a)  All persons desiring to obtain a license required under this chapter shall make written application at the office of the county manager. Such application shall state the name and address of the applicant; the place where the proposed business is to be located; the nature and character of the business to be carried on; if a partnership, the names of partners; if a corporation, the names of the officers and stockholders; and such other information as may be required by the county manager, and be sworn to by the applicant or agent thereof. 
(b)  Each applicant will make an oath that they have read and understand this chapter and understands that all provisions contained herein are applicable to all applicants for retail or pouring licensees. 
(c)  The applicant shall furnish all data, information and records requested of them by the county manager. The county manager shall deny the application of any applicant who fails to furnish such data, information and records within 30 days from the date of request. Upon the county manager's approval that the application is sufficient, the manager shall forward the application to the county zoning administrator to determine if the application meets the requirements set forward in the McIntosh County Zoning Ordinance. 
(d)  For the purpose of this chapter, the term "applicant" shall include in the case of a partnership or corporation all partners, officers, directors and shareholders of such partnership or corporation. 
(e)  All applications for licenses, both original and renewal, must be accompanied by a full and complete statement under oath of information relative to any and all interests, as defined in subsection 6-19(a), in retail alcoholic beverage package stores or establishments offering alcoholic beverages for sale by the drink. This shall include: 
(1)  The names and addresses of all persons interested in the ownership of the business of selling at retail packaged alcoholic beverages or alcoholic beverages for sale by the drink, together with any interest each person or any member of his immediate family has in any other retail alcoholic beverage package store or establishment offering alcoholic beverages for sale by the drink; 
(2)  The ownership of the land and building where such retail business or establishment is operated; 
(3)  The amount of rental paid for such land and building and the manner in which the same is determined and to whom and at what intervals it is paid; and 
(4)  The names and addresses, by affidavit from the owner, lessor or sub-lessor of such land and building, of all persons having any whole, partial, beneficial or other interest in and to the land and building on and in which the retail alcoholic beverage package store or establishment offering alcoholic beverages for sale by the drink is located. 
(f)  Each application for an alcoholic beverage license at a location for which there is no existing county license for the same type of alcoholic beverage license in effect shall include a blue line copy of a surveyor's plat, eight and one-half inches by 11 inches in size, with a scale of one inch equals 200 feet, showing the location of the building or proposed building and location of all customer entries in relation and distance to all real property and buildings on such real property which fall within the distance requirements set forth in section 6-19, together with the zoning classifications and present uses of all such real property. 
(g)  Each application furnished under this section must be complete in its entirety before being accepted by the county for filing and processing. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-11. - Citizenship, residence and age requirements. 
(a)  Where the applicant for a license under this chapter is a corporation, any license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be applied for by and shall be issued to the corporation and either the majority shareholder thereof, or a person employed full-time in a managing capacity by the corporation. 
(b)  Where the applicant for a license under this chapter is a partnership, any license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be applied for by and shall be issued to the partnership and either the managing general partner thereof, or a person employed full-time by the partnership in a managing capacity. 
(c)  Where the applicant for a license under this chapter is a sole proprietor, any license for the sale of alcoholic beverages shall be applied for by and shall be issued to the sole proprietor if he is working full-time in a managing capacity on the premises, and, if not, then the sole proprietor and a person employed full-time by the sole proprietor in a managing capacity. 
(d)  In order to be eligible to hold an alcoholic beverage license, the individual proposed as the licensee must be a U.S. citizen, or a legal alien for at least one year prior to making application, and must be 25 years of age or older at the time the application for a license is filed. 
(e)  If the licensee leaves employment or no longer qualifies as complying with the definition of "managing capacity" the alcoholic beverage license shall be void. However, when filing an application the applicant may identify a substitute licensee, who shall meet all the requirements as the original licensee and shall be approved by the county manager. The substitute licensee may serve as licensee and the alcoholic beverage license shall remain valid in the event that the original licensee no longer qualifies as licensee. 
(f)  The licensee shall notify the county manager in writing of the name(s), addresses and telephone numbers of all managers and employees who are authorized to receive court documents, communications and notices required under this chapter at the location of the business and shall keep such notification current. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-12. - False information in application. 
Any material omission or untrue or misleading information contained in or left out of an original, renewal or transfer application for any license or permit issued under this chapter shall be unlawful, and shall be cause for a denial thereof. If any such license or permit has previously been granted under the above-described circumstances, such shall constitute cause for the revocation of such license or permit. The omission of information relating to a conviction of a crime, be it misdemeanor or felony, shall constitute a material omission for the purposes of this sub-section. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
State Law reference— False swearing, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-71. 
Sec. 6-13. - Sheriff's investigation of applications. 
After the zoning administrator has determined that the application meets the requirements set forth in the zoning ordinance, the application shall be forwarded back to the county manager who shall then forward the application to the sheriff's office. All applications required by this chapter shall be investigated by the sheriff's department, which shall report its recommendation to the county manager. No action shall be taken by the county or by any applicant with respect to any application until the sheriff's department's investigation is completed. The sheriff's department shall make its recommendation within 30 days after receipt of all required information and any additional information requested by the county manager. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-14. - Notice of intent to engage in business. 
All new applications for an alcohol or beverage license at a new location or a location which has been previously denied shall not be granted without a call for a public hearing in the legal organ of the board of commissioners. The notice shall contain information on the pending application including location, license being sought, and name of applicant. The applicant shall pay the county a fee found in appendix A to this Code to cover charges associated with said advertisement. The advertisement shall be made one time within 15 to 45 days of when said application shall be considered by the board of county commissioners. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-15. - Initial consideration of application and appeal. 
(a)  All applications for licenses under this chapter shall be acted upon at the time advertised unless an objection is filed as provided herein. If the application does not meet the legal requirements of this chapter, the county manager shall deny the license. Any license at a location that has not been licensed before shall only be issued by the board of commissioners in addition to any licenses that are seeking reissuance after revocation for any reason. Licenses not requiring approval by the board of commissioners which the county manager may consider shall be acted on by the county manager within 15 days of receipt of the sheriff's office findings. The county manager is authorized to approve or deny the following type licenses which are all at locations previously approved for alcohol licenses by the board of commissioners: 
(1)  Change of ownership or corporation. 
(2)  A new owner or business seeking to obtain a license at a previously approved business. 
(3)  Transfer of license. 
(4)  Modification of license or addition of license. 
(b)  The decision of the county manager shall be transmitted to the applicant by certified mail. Any decision of the county manager shall be final unless appeal is made to the county board of commissioners by an aggrieved party within ten days from the date that the decision of the county manager is mailed to the applicant. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-16. - Circumstances prohibiting issuance. 
(a)  No alcoholic beverage license may be issued where the application or other evidence shows any of the following conditions to exist: 
(1)  That the applicant is of bad moral character or has a bad reputation in the community or does not have sufficient mental capacity to conduct the business for which application is made. 
(2)  That the applicant has had any license issued under the police powers of any county, state, municipality or other governmental entity previously suspended or revoked. 
(3)  That the applicant has violated any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business within a ten-year period immediately preceding the date of application. 
(4)  That any applicant for a retail license under this chapter is related to any distributor or wholesaler of alcoholic beverages or employees thereof within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity. This subsection shall not restrict a farm winery from selling at retail and wholesale. 
(5)  That any applicant or any corporation or partnership of which the applicant is or was an officer, director, shareholder, general partner or managing agent is delinquent in payment of any property tax or other tax or license fee payable to the county or to the state. 
(6)  The applicant has demonstrated lack of knowledge of the county ordinances and federal and state law regulating the business. Prima facie evidence of lack of knowledge, as described in this subsection, would include but is not limited to violations of such law or regulation, regulating the business. 
(7)  The applicant fails to answer questions on the alcoholic beverage application accurately or to provide accurate information to the board of commissioners, county administrator, sheriff, or zoning administrator staff regarding laws and regulations governing the business. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the circumstances set out in subsections (a)(1) through (a)(5) of this section, the county manager or the board of commissioners may waive such circumstances and grant a license. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-17. - Issuance of license to persons with prior convictions. 
No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages for pecuniary gain shall be issued to any person where any individual having an interest either as owner, partner, principal shareholder, or licensee shall have been convicted within the ten-year [period] immediately prior to the consideration of the alcoholic beverage application for any felony or a violation of federal, state, or local law involving moral turpitude, or for the violation of any county, state, or federal law of soliciting for prostitution, pandering, letting premises for prostitution, keeping a disorderly place; or any charge relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages or serious traffic offense as defined in O.C.G.A. § 40-6-390 et seq., the traffic offense of hit and run or leaving the scene of an accident, but excluding any first conviction for driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, or for whom outstanding indictments, accusations or criminal charges exist charging such individual with any of such offenses and for which no final disposition has occurred. If at the time of application the applicant is charged with any of the offenses prescribed in this subsection, consideration of the application shall be suspended until entry of a plea or verdict or dismissal. The board of commissioners may waive this disqualification after hearing in all cases. The applicant shall appeal any disqualification by virtue of this section directly to the board of commissioners without hearing by the county manager. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-18. - Denial on basis of license already held. 
(a)  No retail licensee or person having an interest therein shall have any business or commercial transactions with a wholesaler or manufacturer of alcoholic beverages other than the purchase of and payment for alcoholic beverages. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee or person having an interest therein to have any connection, either directly or indirectly, in any scheme or device to obtain an interest in a retail package store, being more than allowed by this chapter, or to engage in any scheme or device to use another person as a guise or dummy to obtain a retail license. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-19. - Distance requirements—From schools, churches, parks, and other facilities. 
(a)  No person knowingly and intentionally may sell or offer to sell: 
(1)  Any distilled spirits in or within 100 yards of any church building or within 200 yards of any school building, educational building, school grounds, or college campus; 
(2)  Any wine or malt beverages within 100 yards of any school building, school grounds, or college campus; 
(3)  Any distilled spirits, wine or malt beverages within 100 yards of an alcoholic treatment center owned and operated by this state or any county or municipal government therein. 
(4)  As used in this subsection, the term "school building" or "educational building" shall apply only to state, county, city, or church school buildings and to such buildings at such other schools in which are taught subjects commonly taught in the common schools and colleges of the state and which public schools or private schools as defined in O.C.G.A. § 20-2-690(b). 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any new establishment to obtain licensure to sell liquor by the package within 500 yards of an existing establishment with a liquor consumption off premises sales license. 
(b)  All measurements to determine whether the distance requirements set forth in this section have been met shall be measured in accordance with rules and regulations adopted by the Georgia Department of Revenue as now enacted or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Cross reference— Plat filing requirements, section 6-10. 
State Law reference— Sale of alcoholic beverages near churches, schools or college campus, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21; adoption of rules and regulations; determination of location of distilleries or businesses licensed by municipal or county governing authorities, O.C.G.A. § 3-4-49. 
Sec. 6-20. - Same—Exemption for existing establishments. 
Any application for renewal or transfer of a license under this chapter on an existing licensed location shall not be subject to the distance requirements from churches, schools, child day care centers, alcoholic treatment centers, housing authority property, private residences, and other distance requirements set forth in this chapter, nor subject to zoning standards or additional architectural standards as set forth in this chapter. An applicant requesting renewal or transfer of a license under this section must meet all other requirements of this chapter for the granting of a new license. 
In addition, any bar facilities operating before the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall be permitted to continue to operate under the regulations that where in place when their original license was issued. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Cross reference— Penalties, subsection 6-3(a)(1). 
Sec. 6-21. - Additional standards for issuance, renewal, transfer or denial of retail license. 
In addition to the standards stated elsewhere in this chapter, the following standards shall apply for issuance, retention, renewal, transfer or denial of licenses for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages either by the package or for consumption on the premises: 
(1)  Evidence that, even though there is compliance with the minimum distances from schools and churches, the type and number of schools or number of churches in the vicinity causes underage persons to frequent the immediate area. 
(2)  Evidence that the location of the type of structure could create difficulty in police supervision. 
(3)  Evidence that a license for the location would be detrimental to the property values in the area. 
(4)  Evidence that the license in that location would be detrimental to traffic conditions or that there is a lack of sufficient parking which would result in parking on the streets or adjoining property. 
(5)  Evidence that alcoholic beverages have been sold to an intoxicated person or to an underage person. 
(6)  Evidence that the conducting of the business creates a disturbance, congregation of intoxicated persons, congregation of underage persons, or consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises by underage persons, or causes the sheriff to answer excessive complaints or make extra surveillance of the premises. More than three underage persons without supervision of a parent or one authorized by a parent shall be prima facie a congregation of underage persons. "Excessive" is defined as three or more complaints involving the business within any cumulative three months selected. 
(7)  Evidence that any agent or employee of any corporation in which any shareholder of the applicant had any interest, violated any ordinance, law statute regulating the business. 
(8)  In addition to the standards set out in subsections (1) through (7) of this section, the following evidence shall be considered in the public interest and welfare: 
a.  If the applicant is a previous holder of a license, the manner in which he conducted the business there under as to the necessity for unusual police observation and inspection in order to prevent the violation of any law, regulations or ordinance relating to such business. 
b.  If the applicant's spouse shall not be able to meet the qualifications of an applicant, particularly if it appears that the applicant's spouse or another person is using the applicant as a guise or dummy to obtain a license. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-22. - Supplemental requirements for sale of alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption. 
(a)  No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink shall be issued to any applicant that does not meet the requirements of a restaurant as defined in this chapter. 
(b)  A license for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink may be issued to a hotel that includes, on the premises, a restaurant defined in section 6-2, and provided, further, that sales of alcoholic beverages shall be permitted only in the restaurant or as an in-room service provided to guests by the hotel. 
(c)  The square foot area of a bar facility in a restaurant shall not be greater than 25 percent of the square footage of the dining area of the establishment where tables are located excluding kitchen area, hall, restrooms, waiting area, and areas where games or pool tables are located. 
(d)  No bar, other than a bar facility in a restaurant meeting the food sales requirement of a restaurant, nor any bottle house shall be operated in the unincorporated area of the county. 
(e)  Failure to produce satisfactory evidence that a business meets the percentage of food requirement of its total annual food and beverage sales from the sale of food as required to be a restaurant shall be cause for denial or revocation of the alcoholic beverage license. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-23. - Restrictions upon transfers. 
Licenses under this chapter shall not be transferable as to location or ownership, except upon approval of the county manager and issuance of and payment for the license, subject to the following: 
(1)  In case of the death of any person holding such a license or any interest therein, the license may, in the discretion of the county manager, be transferred to the administrator, executor or the lawful heirs of the deceased person. 
(2)  Nothing in this section, however, shall prohibit one or more of the partners in a partnership holding a license to withdraw from the partnership in favor of one or more of the partners who were partners at the time of the issuance of the license. Such a withdrawal shall not, however, serve to bring any new ownership into the partnership. 
(3)  Nothing in this section, however, shall prohibit one or more principal shareholders in a corporation holding a license to withdraw from the corporation, who were principal shareholders at the time of the issuance of the license. Such a withdrawal shall not, however, serve to bring any new ownership into the corporation. 
(4)  Should a transfer of a location be approved, there shall be no pro rata return of any license fee, and the new location shall be considered under and meet the requirements of a new license. 
(5)  It shall be deemed a change of ownership when an owner or licensee adds an additional partner or partners or an additional stockholder or stockholders. 
(6)  All applications for transfer of location shall be posted as required by section 6-14. 
(7)  A change in ownership as set forth in this section requires an application for a new license and the payment of a new license fee according to the procedures in this chapter. 
(8)  It shall be the duty of each licensee to promptly report any changes of any kind in the ownership or distribution of ownership to the county manager. 
(9)  If a licensee desires to sell the business for which the license was issued, the purchaser of the business must be informed by the licensee that the purchaser of the business must make application for and obtain a license prior to operating the business. Any transfer of the business for which the license is issued without the new owners being licensed shall cause the automatic revocation of the license. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-24. - Wholesale licensees prohibited from interest in other licenses. 
No person who has any direct financial interest in a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages at wholesale shall hold any other license under the terms of this chapter. This section shall not apply to farm wineries. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-25. - Temporary event alcohol permit. 
A temporary event alcohol permit may be requested by any group holding a special event that has been approved by the board of commissioners. Such permit shall be for the sale of beer and wine only and the sale of such shall meet all requirements for hours of operation that pertains to other licensed restaurants. 
The applicant must submit a completed application to the county manager along with the special event permit submitted to the clerk of the board of commissioners. A temporary event alcohol permit shall be issued only in conjunction with a special event which has been approved by the board of commissioners. In addition the applicant must obtain a State of Georgia special event alcoholic beverage permit before any sales commence. All applicants who apply for a temporary event alcohol permit must have food available to event attendees for free or for sale. 
A separate application must be made for each location and for each event. No more than six permits may be issued to an organization in any one calendar year and all events must be associated with and benefit the cause of a charitable or civic organization. Any misstatement or concealment of fact in the application shall be grounds for denial or revocation of the license issued and shall subject the applicant to prosecution under the laws of the state. A fee found in appendix A to this Code shall be charged per event per permit. 
The granting of a temporary event alcohol permit is a privilege subject to be annulled and revoked if the applicant is deemed to not conduct the event in accordance with ordinances of the county or the laws of the state. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-26. - Architectural and zoning standards. 
(a)  [ Premises requirements. ] All applicants for licenses for premises that have not previously been in use for the same purpose as applied for shall furnish plans and renderings of the proposed premises. Such premises shall be constructed, renovated or built so as to be equal to and compatible with the surrounding neighborhood or better. The exterior shall be of finished building material such as brick, stone, steel or wood. The applicant shall comply with all building, health and similar county codes. An applicant for retail or pouring license shall obtain and file with his application a certification of zoning compliance, certifying that the property where the applicant shall operate his business is zoned for the appropriate category as provided in this article. 
(b)  Wholesalers. No license shall be issued to a wholesaler of alcoholic beverages unless the wholesaler's business is to be located in an area of the county that is appropriately zoned for the same. 
(c)  Pouring licenses. No pouring license for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink shall be issued unless the location is zoned C-G or C-I under the zoning laws of the county, or is in use as a business under a specific special use permit, provided that this section shall not apply to private clubs as defined in this chapter. No license shall be issued for a location that operates as a nonconforming use. 
(d)  Package sales. No license for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages in package form shall be issued to any person for the operation of such business, except within the areas zoned C-G or C-I. No license shall be issued for a location which is a nonconforming use. No license shall be issued for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the package shall operate under such license unless the front entrance to the licensed premises is clearly visible from the public street; provided, however, that this restriction shall not apply where the licensee is a hotel, motel, or farm winery, or is located in a shopping center or multiple story business building. "Clearly visible" shall mean that not less than 60 percent of the front area shall be glass. "Front area" shall mean the width of the premises from the ceiling to the floor. 
(e)  Farm wineries. A farm winery shall comply with all applicable zoning regulations. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-27. - Hearings and appeals before the county board of commissioners. 
(a)  Applicants who have appealed shall be given written notice of the date, time and place when the county board of commissioners will consider the respective matter. A sign shall be posted by the county manager at the location giving notice of the date, time and place when the county board of commissioners shall consider the application. The applicant and interested parties shall be afforded the opportunity to be heard by the county board of commissioners. 
(b)  Minutes and records of all proceedings before the county board of commissioners shall be kept and maintained in the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners. 
(c)  The county board of commissioners shall consider the matter and shall, by a majority of the required quorum render a written decision not more than 15 days after the date of the hearing. The decision shall be transmitted to the applicant and to all parties that filed objections, if any, by certified mail. 
(d)  The decision of the board of commissioners, unless appealed in accordance with subsection (e) below, shall be final. Should the applicant be denied the applicant will not be entitled to reapply for a period of 180 days. The 180-day period shall begin on the day upon which the denial is deemed final. 
(e)  The decision of the board of commissioners on an appeal under this section shall be final unless appeal is made to the superior court of the county. Any aggrieved party may appeal a decision of the board of commissioners by filing a petition for writ of certiorari to the superior court within 30 days of the decision of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-28. - License to be obtained within two weeks of approval of application. 
(a)  All licenses under this chapter must be obtained and fees paid not later than two weeks from the date of the approval of the application; and if not so obtained, the permit granted shall be void. 
(b)  When a license under this chapter has been approved and the applicant has deposited with the county manager the required fees, the license shall be issued. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Sec. 6-29. - Sunday sales of alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  It shall be lawful for any holder of an alcoholic beverage license with a Sunday sales endorsement to sell alcoholic beverages on Sunday from 12:30 p.m. to 12:00 midnight in any licensed establishment which derives at least 50 percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or food in all of the combined retail outlets of the individual establishment where food is served and in any licensed establishment which derives at least 50 percent of its total gross income from rental of rooms for overnight lodging. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the package sales by retailers of wine/beer/distilled spirits on Sundays between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m., if such Sunday sales of malt beverages, wine and distilled spirits are approved by a majority of the voters of McIntosh County in a referendum called for that purpose. 
(Ord. of 6-11-2013(1); Ord. of 1-14-2014) 
Chapter 8 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(3); dogs and dangerous dogs generally, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-1 et seq.; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; governing authorities of counties are authorized and required in the control of rabies to require regulation or licensing of animals, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-3. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Abandoned animal means any animal: 
(1)  Which shall have been placed upon public property or within a public building unattended and uncared for; 
(2)  Upon or within the private property of another without the express permission of the owner, custodian or tenant of the private property and is unattended or without care; or 
(3)  Which has been upon or within the property of the owner or custodian of this animal for a period of time in excess of 36 hours unattended and without proper food, water and shelter. 
Abandonment shall also include failure to provide reasonable remedy or relief for any injured or diseased animal. 
Animal means and includes the following: 
(1)  Domestic animals. Animals that are accustomed to live in or about the habitation of humans, that are not found naturally in the wild state, including, but not limited to, cats, cattle, dogs, fowl, goats, horses, swine, and various genetically established strains of laboratory/pet animals such as mice, rats, hamsters, gerbils, guinea pigs and rabbits. 
(2)  Feral animals. Domestic animals which have reverted back to a wild state and do not exhibit traits consistent with their intended use. 
(3)  Native wildlife animals. A non-domesticated animal which is normally found in the natural state within the confines of the state. 
(4)  Non-native or exotic wildlife animals. A non-domesticated animal which is not normally found in the natural state within the confines of the state. 
(5)  Domestic/wild animals. An established strain of wild animal which is generally used in the fur or pet industry including, but not limited to, ranch mink, ferrets and brown and white skunks. 
Animal control officer means any person employed by the county as the director, an animal control officer, a county code enforcement officer, any other persons so designated by the county manager, and any certified law enforcement officer. 
Animal shelter or pound means the facilities operated by the county for confining animals impounded or surrendered under the provisions of this chapter. 
Animal under restraint means: 
(1)  Any animal secured by a leash or lead with a collar, or enclosed by way of a fence or other enclosure; 
(2)  Any animal under the supervision of a responsible and competent person at least 14 years of age, obedient to the person's commands, and located within the boundaries of property owned, leased or occupied by the owner; 
(3)  A dog being trained or used to hunt in conformance with the game laws of the state; or 
(4)  A dog owned by a government agency. 
Certificate means a certificate or document issued at the time of vaccination for rabies of a dog or cat and bearing thereon the signature of the vaccinator, the vaccination tag number, the name, color, breed and sex of the dog or cat, the name and address of the owner, and the date of the vaccination. 
County attorney means the McIntosh County Attorney. 
County manager means the McIntosh County Manager. 
Cruelty to animals means the neglect, an act, or an omission, which causes unjustifiable physical pain, suffering or death to any living animal, including without limitation, the injuring, beating, choking, shooting, stabbing, burning, or otherwise physically harming any animal. Causing one dog to engage in a fight with another dog for sport shall constitute an act of cruelty to animals. The term "cruelty to animals" does not include the killing of animals raised for the purpose of providing food nor does it apply to any person who hunts wild animals in compliance with the game and fish laws of the state. 
Current vaccination tag means a metal tag issued by the state department of human resources, or other state agency, which bears a number showing that it is current for a one-year period up to a three-year period for immunization of rabies. 
Director means the chief supervisor of the county animal services activities. 
Fence means a structure of wire, wood, stone, or other materials which is of sufficient height and strength to act as a barrier against passage of the animal it is intended to enclose. The term "fence" also includes so-called "invisible fence" systems which provide an electric shock which prevents an animal from leaving the property of its owner, provided the animal is a dog which is neither vicious nor in estrus. (Dogs which are vicious as defined in this section shall be restrained in an enclosure which not only restrains the animal from leaving the owner's property, but also protects persons who may come onto the property from harm. Female dogs in estrus shall be confined in a conventional enclosure or otherwise restrained in a way which prevents breeding not intended by the owner.) 
Guard dog means any dog which has been trained to attack persons or other animals independently or upon oral command and any dog which, while not so trained, is reasonably expected to perform as a guardian of the property upon and/or within which it is located. 
Humane manner means to provide care for an animal to include, but not necessarily limited to, adequate ventilation and reasonably sanitary shelter, appropriate manner of restraint, wholesome food and water consistent with the normal requirements and feeding habits of the animal's size, species and breed, and necessary veterinary medical care to insure relief from undue pain or suffering. 
Inhumane manner means the failure to provide humane care and shall also mean restraining an animal by affixing to its collar or otherwise attaching to its body a chain, rope, cord, or other lead which is attached to the ground or a fixed object and which is not of sufficient length to allow the animal access to food and water or to move about freely in an area of reasonable size considering the size and nature of the animal. 
Owner means any person owning, keeping, harboring or acting as custodian of an animal for a period of 72 hours or more. 
Person means an individual, firm, corporation, municipality, society or owner. 
Public nuisance means any animal which: 
(1)  Is vicious; 
(2)  Attacks passersby or excites fear of attack by reasonably prudent passersby; 
(3)  Attacks passing vehicles or enters a roadway as if to attack a vehicle; 
(4)  Is found repeatedly at large; 
(5)  Damages property of others; 
(6)  Excessively produces disturbing noises; 
(7)  Female dog while in estrus (in heat, in season) not confined in a manner which can reasonably be expected to keep away or not attract male dogs; or 
(8)  Is inimical to the public health, welfare or safety according to the rules and regulations promulgated by the county board of health, and other appropriate state laws, rules, and regulations, which rules and regulations are incorporated herein and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this chapter. 
Vaccinate means the proper administration, by a licensed veterinarian, of a specified dose of anti-rabies vaccine into a dog or cat. 
Veterinarian means any person who holds a license to practice the profession of veterinary medicine in the state. 
Vicious animal means an animal whose owner knows or reasonably should know presents a danger to humans or other animals because it has: 
(1)  Without provocation, bitten or attacked a person or another animal in the past; or 
(2)  It has exhibited threatening or vicious conduct or propensities toward humans or other animals. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-1-2) 
Sec. 8-2. - Animal control unit. 
There is hereby created the county animal services department under the general supervision of the director of such department, who reports to the county manager. 
(Ord. of 6-7-2005, art. I, § 2-4-2; Res. of 11-7-2008) 
Sec. 8-3. - Jurisdiction. 
This chapter shall apply to and be enforceable in the unincorporated portions of the county. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-1-4) 
Secs. 8-4—8-28. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REGULATIONS 

Sec. 8-29. - Unlawful acts. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to do any of the following acts: 
(1)  Abandon any animal; 
(2)  Fail to keep an animal under restraint; 
(3)  Fail to provide a collar and display on said collar: 
a.  The name and telephone number of the person who owns the animal; and 
b.  The animal's current vaccination tag; 
(4)  Fail to provide care for an animal in a humane manner; 
(5)  Allow any animal to become a public nuisance; 
(6)  Fail to have any dog, cat or ferret vaccinated against rabies; 
(7)  Treat any animal in an inhumane manner; 
(8)  Keep a vicious animal, except as authorized by article V of this chapter; 
(9)  To neglect any animal; 
(10)  Commit an act of cruelty to any animal; 
(11)  To sponsor, participate in or attend an organized dog fight; or 
(12)  To violate any criminal law of the state regarding animals. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-2-1) 
Sec. 8-30. - Unattended animals. 
It shall be unlawful to leave an animal unattended in a parked vehicle without proper ventilation such that will prevent the animal from suffering physical distress from dangerous temperatures, lack of food or lack of water. Animal control officers shall take such action as is necessary, including entry of the vehicle by any reasonable means to remove an animal from such jeopardy, and may impound said animal and secure medical treatment for said animal as needed at the owner's or custodian's expense. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-2-2) 
Sec. 8-31. - Acts of neglect. 
(a)  A person commits an act of animal neglect when such person permits any animal under his care or control to endure one or more of the following conditions: 
(1)  Lack of immediately available proper drinking water or inadequate supply of drinking water. 
(2)  Lack of wholesome, palatable, free from contamination food or sustenance to be provided in sufficient quantity. 
(3)  Failure to provide an animal sufficient space to stand to full height, turn around, lay down and make normal postural adjustments for comfort. 
(4)  The lack of a stationary shelter from weather such as sun, rain, wind or inclement weather or failure to maintain said shelter in a clean and sanitary condition free of excrement and unreasonably objectionable odors. 
(5)  To have an animal in one's possession that is known or suspected to have an injury, accidental or deliberate, or to exhibit obvious signs of disease, tremors, open wounds, inability to eat, abnormal bleeding, partial paralysis, or discharging blood or mucus. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to habitually neglect any animal in any of the manner stated in subsections (1) through (5) of this section. A person habitually neglects an animal when, after being warned by an animal control officer to not neglect an animal, such person, within 60 days thereafter, permits a condition of neglect to exist as to any animal. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-2-3) 
Secs. 8-32—8-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RABIES CONTROL 

Sec. 8-51. - Supplement to state requirement. 
This article is intended to supplement the state requirement of rabies vaccination as provided in O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq., and to provide the county with additional enforcement methods to the extent permitted by law. 
Sec. 8-52. - Vaccination tag. 
It shall be the duty of each dog or cat owner or custodian thereof, to provide a collar for their dog or cat to which a current rabies vaccination tag shall be attached. The collar, together with the tag, shall be worn by the dog or cat at all times, except as provided in this chapter. Failure to comply with this section shall be unlawful and shall be punished as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-3-1) 
Sec. 8-53. - Tag required for dog or cat over four months of age. 
(a)  The owner or custodian of each dog or cat over four months of age kept, maintained or harbored within the unincorporated areas of the county shall apply for and obtain a rabies tag for such dog or cat which shall be affixed to a collar worn by such dog or cat at all times. The director may grant applications upon forms it designates for exemption from this tag display requirement for show dogs or cats wherein the wearing of a collar may cause damage to the coat of the animal. Owners of show dogs or cats shall have in their immediate possession the rabies tag where it may be produced on demand of animal control officer. 
(b)  Any licensed veterinarian shall be authorized to vaccinate dogs or cats against rabies; provided, that at the time of such vaccination said veterinarian shall furnish a vaccination tag issued by the state department of human resources, bearing an official serial number to the owner. Such veterinarian shall furnish a certificate certifying to the vaccination of each dog or cat, shall send one copy of the record of vaccination to the county animal services director, and shall keep a copy for said veterinarian's files. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to attach a vaccination tag or license tag to the collar of any animal for which it was not issued. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-3-2) 
Sec. 8-54. - Duty to report. 
It shall be the duty of any person and any animal control officer knowing of a rabid animal or of an animal showing rabid symptoms, to immediately report such animal to the animal control shelter and give as much pertinent information as possible. The animal control officer and employees of the animal control shelter shall immediately notify the rabies control officer of the county board of health and assist the same in quarantining such rabid and suspected rabid animals. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-3-3) 
Sec. 8-55. - Quarantine. 
(a)  Where rabies has been found to exist in any animal, or where its existence is suspected, quarantine of all such animals shall be maintained and all such animals shall thereupon be immediately confined to the premises designated by the director in a manner approved by state and county health officials. 
(b)  No animal shall be removed from or brought into a quarantined area or premises without prior approval of the director. 
(c)  A quarantine ordered by the director shall be maintained for such period as the director, in consultation with the county board of health, deems necessary to protect the public health. 
(d)  Quarantined areas or premises and areas where rabid animals or animals suspected of rabies remain at large, should be posted by the director with signs which read: "Rabies - Keep Away from Animals!" Such signs should be conspicuously displayed in a place designated by the director. 
(e)  The owner or custodian of each animal subject to a quarantine invoked by the director under terms of this chapter should be notified of the quarantine. 
(f)  The heads of all animals having had rabies or suspected of having had rabies at the time of death shall be submitted to the director for examination by a veterinarian or other authorized person. When necessary, the director can sacrifice an animal for the purpose of submitting brain tissue for rabies analysis. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-3-4) 
Sec. 8-56. - Enforcement. 
While the county board of health shall have primary responsibility for the control of rabies, to the extent such board of health appoints or consents to any the county animal control officer as a rabies control officer, such person shall be empowered to enforce the rabies vaccination requirement and, for purposes of this chapter, continue to be referred to as an animal control officer. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-3-5) 
Secs. 8-57—8-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPOUNDMENT, ADOPTION AND EUTHANASIA 

Sec. 8-86. - Impoundment. 
The county animal control officers are hereby authorized to impound any: 
(1)  Vicious dog or guard dog not confined, chained or muzzled as herein provided; 
(2)  Female dog while in estrus (in heat, in season) not confined within an enclosure which can reasonably be expected to keep away or not attract male dogs; 
(3)  Animal not wearing on its collar the rabies inoculation tag required by the laws of the state; 
(4)  Dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog found in violation of article V of this chapter; and 
(5)  Animal unrestrained in the county. 
The animal shall be confined in the animal shelter or handled as otherwise provided in this article. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-4-1) 
Sec. 8-87. - Notification; disposal. 
(a)  Upon impounding any dog or other animal, the animal services board, by and through its director, animal control officer, county code enforcement officer, or other authorized representative, shall cause to be made a prompt and reasonable effort to locate the animal's owner, possessor or custodian. Upon location thereof, notification of impounding shall be sent to this owner, possessor or custodian. For the purpose of this section, it shall be deemed sufficient notice if a notification of impounding is sent by certified mail to the owner named on the most recent rabies certificate on file at the address indicated thereon. 
(b)  If the dog or animal is not claimed by the owner, possessor or custodian thereof within the time hereinafter specified, or if the impounded dog or animal is not wearing a rabies tag and identification tag or microchip identifying the name, address and telephone number of the owner, possessor or custodian, then and in that event, the director or his authorized representative may dispose of the dog or animal as provided herein. Animals deemed in pain and suffering or to be diseased with contagious pathogens may be sacrificed expeditiously. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-4-2) 
Sec. 8-88. - Return/adoption of animals. 
(a)  The personnel of the animal control shelter shall not return to the owner any animal impounded until the owner of said animal has paid the fees and charges assessed, and until the owner has prepaid for a rabies tag as required by state law, county health department rules, and this chapter. 
(b)  If an animal is not claimed within four calendar days of confinement and is subject to adoption by a private citizen, the following fee schedule shall be utilized: 
(1)  A private citizen may adopt any legally adoptable, unclaimed animal by prepaying for a rabies tag as required by state law and by county health department rules; and 
(2)  The citizen shall be given a choice to either prepay for spay/neuter at the time of adoption and receive a certificate for such service from veterinarians who have agreed to perform such service; or 
(3)  The citizen may enter into a written agreement with the county animal control guaranteeing that sterilization will be performed by a licensed veterinarian within 30 days after acquisition of such animal in the case of an adult animal or within 30 days of the sexual maturity of the animal in the case of an immature animal; 
however, in the instance of either subsection (b)(2) or (3) of this section, the citizen is required to provide a signed statement from the licensed veterinarian performing the sterilization required within seven days after such sterilization attesting that such sterilization has been performed. 
(c)  If an animal is not claimed within four business days of confinement and is subject to adoption by a rescue or rehabilitation organization (as defined/approved in section 8-89), the following fee schedule shall be utilized: 
(1)  A rescue or rehabilitation organization (as defined/approved in section 8-89) may adopt any legally adoptable, unclaimed animal by prepaying for a rabies tag or tags as required by state law and by county health department rules; and 
(2)  The rescue or rehabilitation organization may enter into a written agreement with the county animal services board guaranteeing that sterilization will be performed by a licensed veterinarian within 30 days after the acquisition of such animal in the case of an adult animal or within 30 days of the sexual maturity of the animal in the case of an immature animal; 
however, in the instance of either subsection (c)(1) or (2) of this section, the rescue or rehabilitation organization is required to provide a signed statement from the licensed veterinarian performing the sterilization required within seven days after such sterilization, attesting that such sterilization has been performed. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-4-3) 
Sec. 8-89. - Euthanasia; fees. 
(a)  Any animal, which has been impounded and is not reclaimed by its owner within four calendar days of the date impounded, shall be subject to adoption or rescue. However, any animal not claimed within seven calendar days may be subject to euthanasia by humane methods by a licensed veterinarian or qualified personnel of the animal shelter. 
(b)  If such animal is adopted by a person other than its owner, it may be released upon the prepayment of the cost of rabies vaccination, tags and/or adoption fees as may be assessed by the animal shelter. 
(c)  Surrendered animals may be made available immediately for adoption or rescue and the fees detailed above shall apply. 
(d)  However, if any such animal is adopted by a group or entity which is noncommercial in nature, is licensed by the state, other licensed/regulated by any other appropriate government authority or is a recognized nonprofit 501(C)3 specializing in the rescue and/or rehabilitation of animals, then said impoundment and/or boarding fees shall not apply, but the cost of rabies tags shall be paid unless proof of rabies vaccination is produced. 
(e)  Licensed/regulated rescue or rehabilitation groups or entities which desire to have the aforementioned impoundment and/or adoption fees waived shall make written application with the animal control department requesting the waiver of fees. This application shall consist of a cover letter containing the request and a copy of the relevant licensing, regulation 501(C)3 status. The county manager, or their designee, shall have authority to determine the validity of requests made under these provisions and shall further have the authority to deny requests made by groups or entities that lack the appropriate documentation. 
(f)  The fees for adoption and ancillary services shall be set by the county manager, upon recommendation of the board. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-4-4) 
Secs. 8-90—8-106. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DANGEROUS DOGS AND POTENTIALLY DANGEROUS DOGS 

Sec. 8-107. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Dangerous dog means any dog that, according to the records of an appropriate authority: 
(1)  Inflicts a severe injury on a human being without provocation on public or private property; or 
(2)  Aggressively bites, attacks, or endangers the safety of humans without provocation after the dog has been classified as a potentially dangerous dog and after the owner has been notified of such classification. 
However, see exception to this definition in section 8-119. 
Owner means any natural person or any legal entity, including, but not limited to, a corporation, partnership, firm, or trust owning, possessing, harboring, keeping, or having custody or control of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the county. 
Potentially dangerous dog means any dog that, without provocation, bites a human being on public or private properly. However, see exception to this definition in section 8-119. 
Proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog while on the owner's property securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen, fence, or structure suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. Any such pen or structure shall have secure sides and secure top, and, if the dog is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed or secured in such a manner as to prevent the dog's escape either from over, under, or around the fence or any gates thereto. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the dog. 
Records of an appropriate authority means: 
(1)  Records of any state, county, or municipal law enforcement agency; 
(2)  Records of any county or municipal animal control agency; 
(3)  Records of any county board of health; 
(4)  Records of any federal, state, or local court; or 
(5)  Records of a dog control officer as provided in this article and by the laws of the state. 
Severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery or a physical injury that results in death. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-5-1) 
Sec. 8-108. - Violation. 
(a)  The owner of a dangerous dog who violated the applicable provisions of section 8-112 or 8-113, or whose dangerous dog is subject to confiscation under section 8-114(a) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. In addition to any confinement that might be imposed for a conviction under section 8-114(a), for the second conviction a fine of not less than $500.00 shall be imposed, and for a third or subsequent conviction a fine of not less than $750.00 shall be imposed. 
(b)  The owner of a potentially dangerous dog who violated the applicable provisions of section 8-112 or 8-113, or whose potentially dangerous dog is subject to confiscation under section 8-114(b) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. In addition to any confinement that might be imposed for a conviction under section 8-114(b), for the second conviction a fine of not less than $300.00 shall be imposed, and for a third or subsequent conviction a fine of not less than $500.00 shall be imposed. 
(c)  No owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall be held criminally liable under this article for injuries inflicted by said owner's dog to any human being while on the owner's property. 
(d)  Any animal control officer shall make a report to the county sheriffs department, or other authorized law enforcement agency, all pertinent facts pertaining to an owner of a dangerous dog who knowingly and willfully fails to comply with the provisions of this article and O.C.G.A. § 4-8-28(d) and (e) if the dangerous dog aggressively attacks and causes severe injury or death of a human being. In such cases, the animal control officer shall confiscate the owner's dangerous dog and place the same in quarantine and thereafter destroyed pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-28(e). 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-5-8) 
Sec. 8-109. - Exclusions. 
The terms "dangerous dog" and "potentially dangerous dog," as defined in section 8-107, shall not include the following: 
(1)  A dog that inflicts an injury upon a person when the dog is being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out the law enforcement officer's official duties; and 
(2)  A dog who inflicts an injury within the meaning of this article if the injury was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort, or was tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the dog or had in the past been observed or reported to have tormented, abused, or assaulted the dog or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-5-2) 
Sec. 8-110. - Investigation; notice; hearing. 
(a)  Any animal control officer, upon receiving a report of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such report as may be necessary to determine the validity of such report and whether the dog should be classified as a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog or reclassified as a dangerous dog if previously classified as a potentially dangerous dog. 
(b)  Should the animal control officer determine that a dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog, such animal control officer shall classify such dog accordingly. Such officer shall then notify the dog's owner of such classification. Said notice to the owner shall: 
(1)  Be in writing and mailed by certified mail to the owner's last known address; 
(2)  Include a summary of the dog control officer's findings that formed the basis for the dog's classification as a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog; 
(3)  Be dated and shall state that the owner, within 15 days after the date shown on the notice, has a right to request a hearing on the animal control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; if the 15th day falls on a weekend or county legal holiday, then the owner shall have until the next business day to file his request for a hearing; 
(4)  State that the hearing, if requested, shall be before the county animal services board; 
(5)  State that if a hearing is not requested, the animal control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog will become effective for all purposes on a date specified in the notice, which shall be after the last day on which the owner has a right to request a hearing; and 
(6)  Include a form to request a hearing before the county animal services board and shall provide specific instructions on mailing or delivering such request to the board. 
(c)  When the animal services board receives a request for a hearing as provided for in subsection (b) of this section, the board shall schedule such hearing within 30 days after receiving the request. The board shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail of the date, time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed to the dog owner at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner of the dog shall be given the opportunity to testify and present evidence. In addition, the board shall receive at the hearing such other evidence and hear such other testimony as the board may find reasonably necessary to make a determination either to sustain, modify, or overrule the animal control officer's classification of the dog. 
(d)  Within ten days after the date of the hearing, the animal services board shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog, the notice shall specify the date upon which that determination is effective. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-5-3) 
Sec. 8-111. - Record of hearing. 
The county animal services board shall conduct the hearings provided for in section 8-110. The secretary shall keep minutes of each hearing, board members present, witnesses who present evidence, and the findings of the hearing. The secretary shall maintain the record of the notice or notices mailed to the owners and custodians of animals. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-5-4) 
Sec. 8-112. - Requirements for possession. 
(a)  No one shall have, own, or possess within the county a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog without a certificate of registration issued by the county animal services board. 
(b)  An animal control officer employed by the county shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog if the owner presents to the animal control officer or the animal control officer otherwise finds sufficient evidence of: 
(1)  A proper enclosure to confine the dangerous or potentially dangerous dog; and 
(2)  The posting of the premises where the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is located with a clearly visible sign warning that there is a dangerous dog on the property. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall receive such sign from the animal control office at the time the owner pays the annual registration fee as required in subsection (d) of this section. Such dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog sign shall conform to the design implemented by the state department of natural resources. 
(c)  In addition to the requirements of subsection (b) of this section, the owner of a dangerous dog shall present to the dog control officer evidence of: 
(1)  A policy of insurance in the amount of $25,000.00 issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in the state insuring the owner of the dangerous dog against liability for any personal injuries inflicted by the dangerous dog; or 
(2)  A surety bond in the amount of $25,000.00 or more issued by a surety company authorized to transact business is this state payable to any person injured by the dangerous dog. 
(d)  The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall pay an annual registration fee at the time the annual certificate of registration is issued. The annual registration fee shall be in the amount of $100.00 for potentially dangerous dog, and $200.00 for dangerous dogs. Certificates of registration shall be renewed in the month of the initial registration. 
(e)  The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify an animal control officer employed by the county if the owner is moving to, from, or within the county. 
(f)  The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who is a new resident of the county shall register such dog within 30 days of becoming a new resident. 
(g)  The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who moves to the county from any other county within the state shall register such dog as required by this article within ten days after becoming a resident of the county. 
(h)  The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the animal control officer within 24 hours if such dog is on the loose, is unconfined, has attacked a human, has died, or has been sold or donated. If the dog has been sold or donated, the owner shall also provide the animal control officer with the name, address, and telephone number of the new owner of the dog. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-5-5) 
Sec. 8-113. - Restrictions on permitting outside of proper enclosure. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an owner of a dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is muzzled and restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the physical restraint of a responsible person. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration, but will prevent it from biting any person. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of a potentially dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the restraint of a responsible person. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-5-6) 
Sec. 8-114. - Confiscation; grounds; disposition. 
(a)  A dangerous dog shall be immediately confiscated by an animal control officer or by a law enforcement officer or any other person so authorized if: 
(1)  The owner of the dog does not secure the liability insurance or surety bond required in section 8-112(c); 
(2)  The dog is not validly registered; 
(3)  The dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure; or 
(4)  The dog is outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 8-113(a). 
(b)  A potentially dangerous dog shall be confiscated in the same manner as a dangerous dog if: 
(1)  The dog is not validly registered; 
(2)  The dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure; or 
(3)  The dog is outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 8-113(b). 
(c)  Any dog that has been confiscated under the provision of this section shall be returned to its owner upon the owner's compliance with the provisions of this article as determined by the animal control officer and upon the payment of reasonable confiscation costs of $200.00. In the event the owner has not complied with the provisions of this section within 20 days of the date the dog is confiscated, the dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-5-7) 
Secs. 8-115—8-141. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES 

Sec. 8-142. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The provisions and violations of this chapter may be enforced by the following persons: 
(1)  The county animal services director; 
(1)  The county animal control officer; 
(1)  The county code enforcement officer; 
(1)  Any certified law enforcement officer having jurisdiction within the unincorporated portion of the county; and 
(1)  With the consent of the county attorney, any other persons so designated by the board. 
(b)  Violators may be issued citations as provided by O.C.G.A. §§ 15-10-62 and 15-10-63, and upon citations approved by the county attorney. Violations of this chapter may be prosecuted by the county attorney and/or any person employed by the county as the director, animal control officer, code enforcement officer, any other persons so designated by the board upon approval of the county attorney, and any certified law enforcement officer. Citations for violations shall be filed in the county magistrate court, and in such other courts as permitted by law. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-6-1) 
Sec. 8-143. - Right of officer to defend himself; interference; right of entry. 
(a)  In the performance of his duties pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, any animal control officer or any law enforcement officer assisting in enforcing this chapter may use such force as is necessary to defend themselves from attack by an animal; provided, however, that all efforts should be made to impound an animal without undue harm, injury or danger to the animal, the officer, or to other persons and property. 
(b)  No person shall interfere with, hinder or molest an animal control officer or other authorized officer in the performance of their duty, or seek to release any animal in the custody of the animal control department. 
(c)  Any animal control officer is hereby authorized to enter upon any property for the purpose of investigating alleged violations of this chapter, and/or to seize and impound any animal found to be in violation of chapter. Animal control officers may use any appropriate means necessary to remove an animal in apparent distress which is a closed vehicle. The operator of the said vehicle may be charged with cruelty to animals. Any animal control officer rescuing an animal shall not be liable for damage to private property caused by such officer's reasonable efforts in rescuing any animal in distress. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-6-2) 
Sec. 8-144. - Fine; imprisonment. 
(a)  Any person violating any provision of this chapter may be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 and/or imprisonment in the county jail for a term not to exceed six months; provided, however, the judge shall probate not less than 120 days of any sentence imposed, except as otherwise provided by general law. 
(b)  In the event a sentence is revoked, a defendant shall not serve more than 60 days in a county jail. 
(c)  The court may suspend the service imposed in the case upon such terms and conditions as it may prescribe for the payment of the fine, for performance of community service in lieu of a fine or incarceration, for the payment of restitution to a victim, or other condition relating to the underlying offense. Service of the sentence, when so suspended, shall not begin unless and until ordered by the court having jurisdiction thereof, after a hearing as in cases of revocation of probated sentences, because of the failure or refusal of the defendant to comply with the terms and conditions upon which service of a sentence was suspended. Service of all or any part of any sentence suspended upon such conditions may be ordered to commence by the trial court any time before the expiration of one year from the date of the sentence after a hearing and a finding by the court that the defendant has failed or refused to comply with the terms and conditions upon which service of the sentence was imposed. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-6-3) 
Sec. 8-145. - No liability for damages. 
Consistent with O.C.G.A. § 4-8-30, it is the intent of the county board of commissioners that the owner of a dangerous dog and/or potentially dangerous dog shall be solely liable for injury, death, and damages caused by such dogs. Under no circumstances shall the county board of commissioners, any animal services board member, nor any employee of the county be liable for the act or omission to act in apprehending, seizing, apprehending, quarantine, impounding, or proving care for any dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog. The immunities and protections provided by O.C.G.A. § 4-8-30 are incorporated herein by reference to such state statute and shall extend to benefit and protect the county, its agents, employees, and boards. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-6-4) 
Sec. 8-146. - Disclosure of vaccination records. 
Rabies vaccination records shall be subject to inspection by the director and animal control officers for determination of the ownership and mailing address of the owners of animals. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-6-5) 
Secs. 8-147—8-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - FEES AND REVENUES 

Sec. 8-176. - Fees. 
(a)  All fees and revenues received by the county animal services board shall be the property of the county and shall be accounted for upon receipts and disbursement ledgers. 
(b)  Proceeds from the sale of licenses, impoundment fees, shelter fees, and other fees shall be applied to the annual operating budget of county animal services for the control of rabies, animal control, enforcement and the operation of the animal shelter. 
(c)  A license fee of $50.00 shall be charged for the certificate of registration as required by state law for a potentially dangerous dog. 
(d)  A license fee of $100.00 shall be charged for a certificate of registration as required by state law for a dangerous dog. 
(e)  After the owner has prepaid for a rabies tag, and become fully compliant with state law, county health department rules, and this chapter, animal control officers shall release any impounded animal upon the owner paying the following fees: 
(1)  Upon capture of a dog or cat, but prior to transporting the dog or cat to the animal control shelter: $15.00. 
(2)  Following capture and transport of the dog or cat to the animal shelter: $30.00. 
(3)  Excluding the day of capture and impoundment, the owner shall also pay the sum of $10.00 per day board for each day of confinement. For the purposes of this article, any portion of a day, except the actual day of capture, shall constitute a full day of confinement. 
(4)  For all other animals impounded other than dogs or cats, the owner or custodian shall be charged the base fee in this section, plus actual expenses of care and boarding. 
(Ord. of 4-8-2008, § 1-7-1) 
Secs. 8-177—8-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - McINTOSH COUNTY ANIMAL SHELTER ADVISORY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Oct. 11, 2011, amended the Code by the addition of § 8-177, arts. I—VII; however, at the editor's discretion, said provisions have been redesignated as art. VIII, §§ 8-201—8-207, for purposes of maintaining Code format and allowing future expansion of the Code. 

Sec. 8-201. - Creation; authorization. 
(a)  McIntosh County Animal Shelter Advisory Board created. This organization shall be the animal shelter advisory board, hereafter referred to as the board.
