(a)  Applications. All applications shall be made in writing on forms provided by the county. Applications shall be submitted in duplicate originals. No application shall be deemed accepted unless accompanied by payment of the requisite application fee in U.S. funds, which is set at $250.00. 
(b)  Every application shall state the name and contact information of a responsible representative of the applicant, who shall be available at all times during actual production activity within the county and for a period of not less than one year thereafter; more than one point of contract may be required. 
(c)  The application shall contain a detailed narrative of the scope of production activities, and include drawings, maps or plats to illustrate locations, property boundaries, existing material improvements, planned temporary improvements, curb cuts and driveways, adjoining streets, traffic patterns, and similar information helpful to assess the impact of the proposed activity. 
(d)  When activity is to occur in or near residential areas, personal notice of intent to secure a permit and the place, date and time of the proposed media activity shall be provided by the applicant, within five days of the filing of the application. To the extent feasible, written acknowledgement of the notice shall be obtained from the resident or resident's agent. For purposes of this section, all residential properties within 500 feet of the outside boundaries of the location(s) where production activity is to occur shall be notified. 
(e)  A signed indemnification and hold harmless agreement, in a form acceptable to the county attorney, shall accompany the application, together with a certificate of insurance naming the county as an additional insured. The minimum limits of insurance coverage shall not be less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence. 
(f)  All applications shall be filed with the county manager, or his designee, who may require such additional information as needed to assess the proposed extent and intensity of the production within the County. 
(g)  Permits. All applications shall be approved with specific terms and conditions, or denied, by the county manager, or his designee, in writing. If approved, the county shall issue a permit to the applicant, in writing, with all terms and conditions clearly set forth therein. Low-impact activity applications shall be approved within ten business days of the submission of a complete application and the requisite documents; high-impact activity applications shall be approved within 20 days of the submission of a complete application and the requisite documents. If the application is denied, the county manager, or his designee, shall state in writing, the reasons for denial. An aggrieved applicant may appeal to the board of commissioners at the next regular meeting occurring more than five days following receipt of a written denial. 
(h)  Permits may be denied, in whole or in part, due to prior scheduled events or activities sanctioned or permitted by the county under other provisions of this Code. 
(i)  Any material variation from the approved scope of work permitted shall be grounds for permit revocation, unless the permit is modified in advance by the permittee. 
(Ord. of 05-08-2018(1)) 
Sec. 19-8. - Fees and waivers. 
(a)  Initial application fees for activity permits, regardless of the level of impact, shall be $250.00. Application fees are non-refundable and must be paid, in full, at the time of application. 
(b)  Daily permit fees of $100.00 for each calendar day on which production activity physically occurs within the county shall be paid upon the last day of the scheduled activity. If a production is scheduled for a duration in excess of a calendar month, the accrued daily fee shall be due and payable on the last day of each month in which production activity occurred. 
(c)  Additional fees and charges may be assessed based upon specific or special services by a county department, based upon labor, time and equipment necessary to provide the service. When using county-owned buildings or property other than public road rights-of-way, for production activities, a separate rental fee or charge may be negotiated. 
(d)  Application fees and daily permit fees for use of county services or facilities may be reduced or waived for charitable or non-profit organizations holding Section 501(c) status from the United States Internal Revenue Service. All waivers shall require approval of the county manager, which may delay permit issuance. 
(Ord. of 05-08-2018(1)) 
Sec. 19-9. - Media production liaison. 
The county manager is hereby expressly authorized to designate an individual as the county's media production liaison to work with and be the county's point of contact with media productions, to assist in coordinating the permitting process for the county, and to promote the county as a "camera ready community" under a program with the Georgia Office of Film, Music and Digital Entertainment. In making such designation, the county manager shall define the duties, compensation and benefits of such individual. 
(Ord. of 05-08-2018(1)) 
Sec. 19-10. - Severability. 
Should any provision of this chapter be rendered invalid by any court of law, the remaining provisions shall continue in force and effect until amended or repealed by action of the county governing authority. 
(Ord. of 05-08-2018(1)) 
Chapter 20 - FLOODS 

Sec. 20-1. - Appointments. 
(a)  The county planning and zoning commission is vested with the responsibility, authority, and means to: 
(1)  Delineate or assist the administrator at his request, in delineating the limits of the areas having special flood hazards on available local maps of sufficient scale to identify the location of building sites. 
(2)  Provide such information as the administrator may request concerning present uses and occupancy of the floodplain. 
(3)  Cooperate with federal, state and local agencies and private firms which undertake to study, survey, map, and identify floodplain or mud slide areas, and cooperate with neighboring communities with respect to management of adjoining floodplain and/or mud slide areas in order to prevent the aggravation of existing hazards. 
(4)  Submit on the anniversary date of the community's initial eligibility an annual report to the administrator on the progress made during the past year within the community in the development and implementation of floodplain management measures. 
(b)  The county planning and zoning commission appoints the chief tax appraiser of the county to maintain for public inspection and to furnish upon request a record of elevation of the lowest floor of all new or substantially improved structures located in the special flood hazard areas. If the lowest floor is below grade on one or more sides, the elevation of the floor immediately above must also be recorded. 
(Res. of 9-3-1975, §§ 1—4) 
Sec. 20-2. - Building inspector and zoning board of appeals appointed. 
The building and zoning inspector is designated as the administrator of the flood plan. The board of zoning appeals is designated to hear and decide appeals under the flood regulations. 
(Res. of 3-20-1984) 
Chapter 22 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted Jan. 12, 2016, repealed the former ch. 22, §§ 22-1—22-4, and enacted a new ch. 22 as set out herein. The former ch. 22 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from §§ I—IV of an ordinance adopted Jan. 30, 1987. 

Sec. 22-1. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  There are currently in existence certain rules and regulations adopted by the McIntosh County Board of Health with the purpose of preserving the public health, safety, and welfare of citizens or those individuals found within the boundaries of McIntosh County, Georgia. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, or other entity to operate a food or tourist establishment, body art studio, septic system, individual water supply system or public and semi-public swimming pool, spa or recreational park or approve a subdivision in McIntosh County without a valid permit or approval issued by the McIntosh Board of Health, in accordance to applicable rules and regulations. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a food or tourist establishment, body art studio, septic system, individual water supply system or public or semi-public swimming pool, spa or recreational park during any period of time that a permit for such operation has been suspended or revoked by the McIntosh Board of Health. 
(3)  No building permit for the construction of any residence, building or other facility which is to be served by a septic tank shall be issued by or pursuant to the authority of the McIntosh Board of Commissioners unless a septic tank construction permit has been issued by the McIntosh County Board of Health. 
(Ref: The Zoning Ordinance of McIntosh County Georgia, Article Nine, Section 901, B(1)(a). 
(4)  Further, no business license or certificate of occupancy shall be issued for any public health regulated establishment or operation unless an approval by the McIntosh Board of Health has been issued. 
(Ref: The Zoning Ordinance of McIntosh County Georgia, Article Nine, Section 901, B(1)(b). 
(b)  This chapter specifically incorporates by reference the provisions of the following rules and regulations and fee schedules which are in force at the time of the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived: 
(1)  Rules and regulations pertaining to food service adopted by the department of public health and the McIntosh County Board of Health and being Chapter 511-6-1 as subsequently amended and updated, and policies of the McIntosh County Board of Health pertaining to food service; 
(2)  Rules and regulations pertaining to tourist accommodations adopted by the department of public health and the McIntosh County Board of Health and being Chapter 511-6-2 as subsequently amended and updated, and policies of the McIntosh County Board of Health pertaining to tourist accommodations; 
(3)  Rules and regulations for on-site sewage management systems and guidance manual adopted by the department of public health and the McIntosh County Board of Health and being Chapter 511-3-1 as subsequently amended and updated, and policies (minimum lot sizing added June 13, 2006) of the McIntosh County Board of Health pertaining to on-site sewage management systems; 
(4)  Rules and regulations for portable sanitation contractors adopted by the department of public health and the McIntosh County Board of Health and being Chapter 511-5-6 as subsequently amended and updated, and policies of the McIntosh County Board of Health pertaining to portable sanitation contractors; 
(5)  Rules and regulations pertaining to drinking water supply adopted by the McIntosh County Board of Health (September 4, 1986) as subsequently amended and updated, and policies of the McIntosh County Board of Health pertaining to drinking water supply; 
(6)  Rules and regulations pertaining to public and semi-public swimming pools, spas, and recreational water parks adopted by the McIntosh County Board of Health (May 7, 2007) and policies of the McIntosh County Board of Health pertaining to public and semi-public swimming pools, spas, and recreational water parks; 
(7)  Rules and regulations pertaining to tattoo/body piercing studios and tattoo/body piercing artists adopted by the McIntosh County Board of Health (August 28, 2007) and being Rules and Regulations for Body Art Studios and Artists as subsequently amended and updated, and policies of the McIntosh County Board of Health pertaining to tattoo/body piercing studios and tattoo/body piercing artists; 
(8)  McIntosh County Board of Health Rules and Regulations for the Control of Rabies (August 30, 2005) as subsequently amended and updated and policies of the McIntosh County Board of Health pertaining to rabies control; and the Georgia Rabies Control Manual; 
(9)  McIntosh County Environmental Health Fee Schedule approved by the McIntosh County Board of Health and adopted by the McIntosh County Commission as subsequently amended and updated, and policies and resolutions of the McIntosh County Board of Health pertaining to fees; 
(10)  Rules and regulations pertaining to "hand watering" gray water regulations adopted by the Department of Public Health (O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2) and the McIntosh County Board of Health (February 25, 2009) as subsequently amended and updated, and policies of the McIntosh County Board of Health pertaining to "hand watering" gray water; 
(11)  Rules and regulations pertaining to Georgia Smokefree Air Act of 2005 adopted by the department of public health (Chapter 511-3-7) and the McIntosh County Board of Health being rules and regulations for Georgia Smokefree Air Act of 2005 as subsequently amended and updated and policies of the McIntosh County Board of Health (October 19, 2005) pertaining to the Georgia Smokefree Air Act of 2005. 
(Ord. of 1-12-2016(1)) 
Sec. 22-2. - Implementation and enforcement. 
The duty of implementation and enforcement of these regulations rest with the McIntosh County Board of Commissioners and by virtue of this chapter is hereby expressly delegated to the McIntosh County Board of Health who is hereby charged with promulgation of sufficient procedures for insuring compliance with these rules and regulations by the citizens of McIntosh County or those individuals found within the boundaries of McIntosh County. The McIntosh County Board of Health is directed to implement procedures which will insure that the citizens of McIntosh County or those individuals found within the boundaries of McIntosh County will receive all procedural rights to which they are entitled under the laws of the State of Georgia: 
(1)  When the duly authorized agent of the McIntosh Board of Health determines that a violation of this chapter exists, he shall send by regular mail, certified mail or personally deliver a written notice of the violation to the owner of the property or his representative, the tenant or his representative and any other party who has control or ownership of the property. The notice of violation may also be personally served or served notoriously by placing on or adjacent to the front door in a conspicuous location. 
(2)  The notice shall state the location of the property, the nature of the violation, a provision for remedying the violation and a timeframe for compliance. The notice shall also state that if the violation is not remedied within the timeframe, a citation for the violation may be issued to all parties controlling or owning the property. 
(3)  Following the expiration of the time set forth in the notice, the duly authorized agent of the McIntosh Board of Health shall re-inspect the property to determine if the violation still exists. 
(4)  If the violation has not been remedied at the time of re-inspection, a citation/summons to court may be issued by a code enforcement officer or law enforcement personnel pursuant to (O.C.G.A § 15-10-63). However, in lieu of a citation, an accusation may be drafted and personally served. 
(5)  If the district environmental health director, district program director or district health director determines that an emergency exists such that there is imminent harm or peril to life or property, he may authorize the immediate issuance of a citation or accusation without the notice that is specified in subsection (1) of this section. Furthermore, lack of the notice letter specified in subsection (2) of this section shall not invalidate a citation or accusation. 
(Ord. of 1-12-2016(1)) 
Sec. 22-3. - Violations and penalties. 
Any violation of the rules and regulations hereby referenced shall be a violation of this chapter and shall be a misdemeanor offense. Any violator shall be subject to the imposition of a fine not to exceed $500.00 and/or imprisonment for a period not to exceed 60 days or both. Any failure of payment of inspection or other environmental service fees listed within the fee schedule approved by the McIntosh County Board of Health and adopted by the McIntosh County Board of Commissioners within 60 days of the first notice may result in suspension of permit. 
(Ord. of 1-12-2016(1)) 
Sec. 22-4. - Magistrate's court jurisdiction. 
The Magistrate's Court of McIntosh County shall have jurisdiction over violators of this chapter and all procedures for enforcement of such ordinance shall be as provided in O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq. Complaints of violation of any provision of this chapter shall be brought before the magistrate's court by a designated representative of the McIntosh County Board of Health and shall be prosecuted through that court. A complaint shall be brought before the magistrate's court only after all notices and rights to a hearing before a hearing officer of the board of health (or their designee) have been provided and/or all applicable McIntosh Board of Health and/or Department of Public Health compliance procedures have been exhausted. 
(Ord. of 1-12-2016(1)) 
Chapter 24 - HISTORIC PRESERVATION 
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Definitions. 
Words and phrases used in this chapter shall have the following meanings, unless otherwise specified: 
Building official means the building official of McIntosh County. 
Certificate of appropriateness means a document evidencing approval by the county historical preservation commission of an application to make a material change in the appearance of a designated historical property or of a property located within a designated historic district. 
Commission means the county historic preservation commission. 
Designated districts and sites means a historic district or historic property. 
Exterior architectural features means the architectural style, general design, and general arrangement of the exterior of a building or other structure, including but not limited to the kind of texture of the building material and the type and style of all windows, doors, signs, and other appurtenant architectural fixtures, features, details or elements relative to the foregoing. 
Exterior environment features means all those aspects of the landscape or the development of the site which affect the historical character of the property. 
Historic district means a geographically definable area which contains structures, sites, works of art, or a combination thereof, which exhibit a special historical, architectural, or environmental character as designated by the county board of commissioners. 
Historic property means an individual structure, site, or work of art which exhibits a special historical, architectural or environmental character as designated by the county board of commissioners. 
Material change in appearance means a change that will affect either the exterior architectural or environmental features of a property within a designated district or site and may include any one of the following: 
(1)  A reconstruction or alteration of the size, shape, or facade and existing building or structure of a historic property, including any of its architectural elements or details. 
(2)  Demolition or relocation of a building or a structure. 
(3)  Commencement of excavation. 
(4)  A change in the location of advertising visible from the public right-of-way. 
(5)  The erection, alteration, restoration or removal of any building or other structure. 
(6)  The construction or removal of exterior environmental features. 
(7)  The application of paint, varnish, stain or other coating to an existing building or structure visually different from the type presently in use. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. XI) 
Sec. 24-2. - Violations. 
Violations of any provisions of this chapter shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-9. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. VII, § 141) 
Sec. 24-3. - Purpose. 
(a)  In support and furtherance of its findings and determination that historic/aesthetic resources of the county are among its most valued and important assets and that the preservation of this heritage is essential to the promotion of the health, prosperity and general welfare of the people. 
(b)  In order to provide a uniform process for providing guidance to owners of historic property in making material changes through the approval of certificates of appropriateness. 
(c)  In order to stimulate revitalization and reinvestment in the central business district and residential areas of the county and to protect and enhance local and historic/aesthetic attractions to tourists and thereby promote and stimulate business. 
(d)  In order to enhance the opportunities for federal tax relief of property owners under relevant provisions of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 (Public Law 99-514) allowing tax investment credits for rehabilitation of certified historic structures. 
(e)  The board of commissioners for the county hereby declare it to be the purpose and intent of this chapter to establish a uniform procedure for use in providing for the protection, enhancement, perpetuation, and use of places, districts, sites, buildings, structures, and works of art having a special historic/aesthetic interest or value, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. I, § 101) 
Sec. 24-4. - Creation of the commission. 
There is hereby created a commission whose title shall be "the McIntosh County Historic Preservation Commission" (hereinafter referred to as "commission"). 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. II, § 102) 
Sec. 24-5. - Commission position within the county government. 
(a)  The county historic preservation commission shall be considered a part of the planning functions of the county. 
(b)  The commission shall consist of seven members appointed by the board of commissioners, who shall be residents of the county, who demonstrated special interest, experience, or education in history, architecture or the preservation of historic resources. 
(c)  Members shall serve three year terms. 
(d)  Members may not serve more than two consecutive terms. 
(e)  In order to achieve staggered terms, the initial appointment shall be as follows: 
(1)  Two members for one year; 
(2)  Two members for two years; and 
(3)  Three members for three years. 
(f)  Members do not receive a salary although they may be reimbursed for expenses. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. II, § 103) 
Sec. 24-6. - Statement of the commission's powers. 
The county historic preservation commission shall be authorized to: 
(1)  Prepare an inventory of all property within its respective jurisdiction having the potential for designation as historic property. 
(2)  Recommend to the board of commissioners for the county specific places, sites, buildings, works of art and districts to be designated by ordinance as historic proportion or historic districts. 
(3)  Review applications for certificates of appropriateness, and grant or deny same in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(4)  Recommend to the board of commissioners for the county that the designation of any place, district, site, building, structure, or work of art as an historic property or as an historic district be revoked or removed. 
(5)  Restore or preserve any historic properties acquired by the county. 
(6)  Promote the acquisition by the county of facade easements and conservation easements in accordance with the provisions of the Facade and Conservation Easements Act of 1976 (1976 Ga. L. (1280), page 1181). 
(7)  Conduct an educational program on historic properties located within its historic preservation jurisdiction. 
(8)  Make such investigations and studies of matters relating to historic preservation as the local governing body or the commission itself may, from time to time, deem necessary or appropriate for the purposes of preserving historic resources. 
(9)  Seek out state and federal funds for historic preservation, and make recommendations to the county concerning the most appropriate uses of any funds acquired. 
(10)  Submit to the historic preservation section (HPS) of the department of natural resources (DNR) a list of historic properties or historic districts designated and provide the HPS whatever information is needed to nominate these to the National Register of Historical Places. 
(11)  Perform historic preservation activities as the official agency of the county preservation program. 
(12)  Employ persons, if necessary, to carry out the responsibilities of the commission; the commission shall not obligate the county without prior consent. 
(13)  Receive donations, grants, funds, or gifts of historic property, and to acquire and sell historic properties. The commission shall not obligate the county without prior consent. 
(14)  Review and make comments to the state historic preservation office concerning the nomination of properties within its jurisdiction to the National Register of Historical Places. 
(15)  Participate in private, state and federal historic preservation programs and with the consent of the board of commissioners enter into agreements to do the same. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. II, § 104) 
Sec. 24-7. - Commission's power to adopt rules and standards. 
(a)  The commission shall adopt rules and standards for the transaction of its business and consideration of applications for designations and certificates of appropriateness, such as bylaws, removal of membership provisions, and design guidelines and criteria. The commission shall have the flexibility to adopt rules and standards without amendment to this division. The commission shall provide for the time and place of regular meetings and a method for the calling of special meetings. The commission shall select such officers as it deems appropriate from among its members. A quorum shall consist of a majority of the members. 
(b)  The latest edition of Robert's Rules of Order shall determine the order of business at all meetings. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. II, § 105) 
Sec. 24-8. - Commission's authority to receive funding from various sources. 
The commission shall have the authority to accept donations and shall ensure that these funds do not displace appropriated governmental funds. The commission will not financially obligate the county with the approve of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. II, § 106) 
Sec. 24-9. - Records of commission meetings. 
A public record shall be kept of the commissions resolution, proceedings and actions. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. II, § 107) 
Sec. 24-10. - Conflict of interest. 
At any time the commission reviews a project in which a member of the commission has ownership or other vested interest, the member will be forbidden from presenting, voting or discussing the project, other than answering a direct question. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. II, § 108) 
Secs. 24-11—24-26. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DESIGNATION OF HISTORIC DISTRICTS AND HISTORIC PROPERTY 

Sec. 24-27. - Preliminary research by the commission. 
(a)  Commission's mandate to conduct a survey of local historical resources. The commission shall have the authority to compile and collect information and conduct surveys of historic resources within the county. Information gathered previously in national register nominations and in earlier surveys may be used. 
(b)  Commission's power to recommend districts and property to the board of commissioners for designation. The commission shall present to the board of commissioners recommendations for the designation of historic districts and historic properties. 
(c)  Preparation of a report on proposed historic districts and historic properties. The commission shall prepare formal reports when recommending historic districts or properties for designation. These reports shall consist of three parts: 
(1)  A list of property classifications as outlined in this chapter. 
(2)  A physical description. 
(3)  A description of the cultural, architectural, and/or the historic/aesthetic significance of the historic district/property. 
These reports will be used to educate the public and provide a permanent record of local designation. A nomination to the national register of historic places and a list of property classifications may suffice as one of these reports. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. III, § 109) 
Sec. 24-28. - Designation of historic districts. 
(a)  Designation. A historic district is a geographically definable area, which contains structures, sites, works of art, or a combination thereof, which satisfies one or more of the following: 
(1)  Have special character or special historic/aesthetic value or interest. 
(2)  Is important to the history of the county, state, or coastal area. 
(3)  Have a majority of structures which are 50 years or older. 
(4)  Cause such area, by reason of such factors, to constitute a visibly perceptible section of the county. 
(b)  Boundaries of an historic district. Boundaries of an historic district shall be specified on tax maps and on the official zoning map. These boundaries will be included in a separate ordinance designating local historic districts and boundaries specified in legal notices shall coincide with the boundaries finally designated. 
(c)  Evaluation of properties within designated historic districts. Areas within historic districts shall be classified as follows: 
(1)  Historic. More than 50 years old and contributing to the district. 
(2)  Non-historic. Less than 50 years old yet possessing architectural character. 
(3)  Intrusions. Buildings of any age which detract from the historical character of the district. 
(d)  Affirmation of existing zoning. This chapter is not a use ordinance. Any zoning laws currently in existence in the county or passed in the future will not be affected by this chapter. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. III, § 110) 
Sec. 24-29. - Designation of historic property. 
(a)  Criteria for selection of historic property. A historic property is a structure, site, work of art, including the adjacent area necessary for the proper appreciation or use thereof, deemed worthy of preservation by reason of value to the county, state, or the coastal area, for one or more of the following reasons: 
(1)  It is an outstanding example of a structure representative of its era. 
(2)  It is one of the few remaining examples of past architectural style. 
(3)  It is a place or structure 50 years or older associated with an activity, an event, or person of historic or cultural significance to the county, state, or the coastal area. 
(4)  It is a property of historic/aesthetic interest that pertains to the cultural or historical development and heritage of the county, state, or the coastal area. 
(b)  Boundaries of a historic property. Boundaries of a historic property shall be specified on tax maps located on the official zoning map. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. III, § 111) 
Sec. 24-30. - General matters affecting the designation of historic districts and historic properties. 
(a)  Application for designation of historic district and landmarks. 
(1)  Historic district. A historical society, neighborhood association or group of property owners, may apply to the commission for designation; 
(2)  Historic property. A historical society, property owner or neighborhood association may apply to the commission for designation. 
(b)  Required public hearings. 
(1)  The commission and the county shall hold a public hearing on the proposed ordinance for designation. Notice of the hearing shall be published in at least three consecutive issues in the legal organ of the county, and written notice of the hearing shall be mailed by the commission to all owners and occupants of such properties. 
(2)  All such notices shall be published or mailed not less than ten nor more than 20 days prior to date set for the public hearing. A letter sent via the United States mail to the last known owner of the property, as recorded on the tax rolls in the county tax assessor's office, shall constitute legal notification under this chapter. 
(c)  Notification of property owners of proposed designation. Any ordinance recommending any property or district as historic for designation shall do the following: 
(1)  Describe each property to be designated. 
(2)  Set forth the names of the owners of the properties to be designated. 
(3)  After designation of the area a certificate of appropriateness must be obtained from the county historic preservation commission prior to any material change in appearance to the property. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. III, § 112) 
Sec. 24-31. - Requirements regarding district boundaries. 
Any ordinance designating any property as a historic property, or as part of a historic district area shall require that the designated property or district be shown on the official zoning map of the county and kept as public record to provide notice of such designation. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. III, § 113) 
Sec. 24-32. - Notification of state department of natural resources historic preservation. 
(a)  Prior to the recommendation of the designation of any property or district as historic, the commission must submit a report on the historic, cultural architectural, or aesthetic significance of each place, district, site building/structure, or work of art, to the HPS of DNR, 30 days will be allowed to prepare written comments. 
(b)  Once a historic district or historic property has been designated by the board of commissioners, the commission shall work with the Coastal Georgia Regional Development Center (CGRDC), historical preservation planner to provide whatever additional information is needed by the HPS to nominate the designated district or site to the national register of historical places. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. III, § 114) 
Sec. 24-33. - Ordinance for final adoption of recommendation. 
Within 15 days of the public hearing, the historic preservation commission shall forward to the board of commissioners a recommendation on the proposed historic district. The board of commissioners shall have the authority to approve, reject or modify the proposed historic district. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. III, § 115) 
Sec. 24-34. - Notification of adoption of ordinances for designation. 
Within 30 days immediately following the adoption of the ordinance for designation, the owners and occupants of each designated historic property, and the owners and occupants of each structure, site, or work of art located within a designated historic district shall be given written notification of such designation by the board of commissioners, which notice shall apprise all owners and occupants of the necessity of obtaining a certificate of appropriateness for undertaking any material change in appearance of a property which is a part of a designated district or site. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. III, § 116) 
Sec. 24-35. - Notification of other agencies regarding designation. 
The county historic preservation commission shall notify all necessary agencies within the county of the ordinance for designation, including the board of commissioners, the office of the building official (inspector) and the zoning official. The commission will also notify individuals and agencies throughout the county, state and coastal area likely to be interested in the ordinance. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. III, § 117) 
Sec. 24-36. - Moratorium on applications for alteration or demolition while ordinance for designation is pending. 
If an ordinance for designation is being considered, the county historic preservation commission shall have the power to freeze the status of the involved property. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. III, § 118) 
Secs. 24-37—24-51. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - APPLICATION TO PRESERVATION COMMISSION FOR CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS 

Sec. 24-52. - Approval of alterations to the exterior architectural features of existing buildings in historic districts or historic properties. 
After the designation by ordinance of a historic district or a historic property, no material change in the exterior architectural appearance of any existing building within these areas shall be permitted to be made by the owner or occupant thereof unless or until application for certificate of appropriateness has been submitted to and approved by the commission. The certificate of appropriateness will certify that the change in exterior architectural appearance is compatible with the historical features of the building altered and the adjoining properties. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 119) 
Sec. 24-53. - Approval of new construction within historic districts or properties. 
The county preservation commission shall issue certificate of appropriateness to new structures constructed within designated historic districts if these structures conform in design, scale, building materials, setback and landscaping to the character of the district specified in the design criteria developed by the commission. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 120) 
Sec. 24-54. - Guidelines and criteria for certificates of appropriateness. 
When considering applications for certificates of appropriateness to existing buildings, the Secretary of the Interior's Standards for Rehabilitation shall be used as a guideline along with any other criteria adopted by the commission. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 121) 
Sec. 24-55. - Submission of plans to commission. 
(a)  In order for an application for a certificate of appropriateness to be reviewed, it must be submitted at least 15 days prior to a scheduled meeting of the commission. 
(b)  An application for certificate of appropriateness shall be accompanied by such drawings, photographs or plans as may be required by the commission. 
(c)  Applications involving demolition or relocation shall be accompanied by post-demolition or relocation plans for the site. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 122) 
Sec. 24-56. - Acceptable commission reaction to application for certificate of appropriateness. 
(a)  The commission shall approve the application and issue a certificate of appropriateness if it finds that the proposed material changes in the appearance would not have a substantial adverse effect on the aesthetic, historic, or architectural significance and value of the historic property or the historic district. In making this determination, the commission shall consider, in addition to any other pertinent factors, the historical and architectural features involved, and the relationship thereof to the exterior architectural style, and pertinent features of the other structures in the immediate neighborhood. 
(b)  The commission shall deny a certificate of appropriateness if it finds that the proposed material changes in the appearance would have a substantial adverse effect on the aesthetic, historic, or architectural significance and value of the historic property or the historic district. 
(c)  The commission may make approval of a certificate of appropriateness conditional upon complying to certain situations which may be listed in the certificate. Such stipulations are to be used only to diminish the adverse impact of the changes in material appearance proposed in the application for a certificate of appropriateness. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 123) 
Sec. 24-57. - Public hearings on applications for certificates of appropriateness, notices and right to be heard. 
At least seven days prior to review of a certificate of appropriateness, the commission shall take such action as may reasonably be required to inform the owners of any property likely to be affected materially by the change in material appearance for which the application for certificate of appropriateness has been made and shall give the applicant and such owners an opportunity to be heard. All meetings of the commission, at which application for certificates of appropriateness are being discussed, shall be open to the public. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 124) 
Sec. 24-58. - Interior alterations. 
In its review of applications for certificates of appropriateness, the commission shall not consider interior arrangement or use having no effect on exterior architectural features. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 125) 
Sec. 24-59. - Technical advice. 
When dealing with technical questions, the commission shall have the power to seek expert advice. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 126) 
Sec. 24-60. - Deadline for approval or rejection of application for certificate of appropriateness. 
The commission should approve or reject an application for a certificate of appropriateness within 45 days after the filing thereof by the owner or occupant of an historic property within a designated historic district or site. Evidence of approval shall be a certificate of appropriateness issued by the county historic preservation commission. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 127) 
Sec. 24-61. - Necessary actions to be taken by the county historic preservation commission upon rejection of application for certificate of appropriateness. 
(a)  In the event the commission rejects an application, it shall state its reasons for doing so, and shall transmit a record of such actions and reasons, in writing, to the applicant. 
(b)  The commission may suggest alternative courses of action it thinks proper if it disapproves the application submitted. The applicant, if he so desires, may make modifications to the plans and may resubmit the application at any time after so doing. 
(c)  In cases where the application covers a material change in the appearance of a structure which would require the issuance of a building permit, the rejection of the application for a certificate of appropriateness by the commission shall be binding upon the building official, inspector or other administrative officer charged with issuing building permits and in such a case, no building permit shall be issued. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 128) 
Sec. 24-62. - Undue hardship. 
Where, by reason of unusual circumstances, the strict application of any provision of this chapter would result in the exceptional practical difficulty or undue hardship upon any owner of a specific property, the commission, in passing upon applications, shall have the power to vary or modify strict adherence to said provisions, or to interpret the meaning of said provisions, so as to relieve such difficulty or hardship; provided such variances, modifications, or interpretations shall remain in harmony with the general purpose and intent of said provisions, so that the architectural or historical integrity, or character of the property, shall be conserved and substantial justice done. In granting variances, the commission may impose such reasonable and additional stipulations and conditions as will, in its judgment, best fulfill the purpose of this chapter. An undue hardship shall be a situation not of the person's own making. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 129) 
Sec. 24-63. - Issuance of stop work orders as required by the commission. 
The building official shall issue stop work orders for projects within the preservation jurisdiction of the commission upon order of the commission if: 
(1)  Work has begun which requires a certificate of appropriateness without such certificate of appropriateness. 
(2)  Work has begun with an expired certificate of appropriateness. 
(3)  It is not done in accordance with an issued certificate of appropriateness. 
In all such cases the owners of the projects involved may apply for a certificate of appropriateness and upon the issuance of a certificate of appropriateness, the stop work order will be removed immediately. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 130) 
Sec. 24-64. - Certificate of appropriateness void if construction not commenced. 
A certificate of appropriateness shall become void unless construction is commenced within six months of the date of issuance. Certificates of appropriateness shall be issued for a period of 18 months and are renewable. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 131) 
Sec. 24-65. - Recording of applications for certificates of appropriateness. 
The commission shall keep a public record of all applications for certificates of appropriateness, and of all the commission's proceedings in connection with said applications. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 132) 
Sec. 24-66. - Acquisition of property. 
The commission may, where such action is authorized by the board of commissioners, and is reasonably necessary or appropriate for the preservation of a unique historic property, enter into negotiations with the owner for the acquisition by gift, purchase, exchange, or otherwise, of the property or any interest therein. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 133) 
Sec. 24-67. - Appeals. 
Any person adversely affected by any determination made by the commission relative to the issuance or denial of a certificate of appropriateness may appeal such determination to the county board of commissioners. The appeal must be applied for within 15 days after notification is sent by the commission. The county board of commissioners may approve, modify, or reject the determination made by the commission if the board of commissioners finds the commission abused its discretion in reaching its decision by violating procedures set forth in this chapter. Appeals to the county board of commissioners may be appealed to a superior court of the county in a manner provided by law for appeals from conviction or ordinance violations. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. IV, § 134) 
Secs. 24-68—24-83. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DEMOLITION OR RELOCATION APPLICATIONS OF AN HISTORIC PROPERTY OR PROPERTIES WITHIN AN HISTORIC DISTRICT 

Sec. 24-84. - Authority to review demolition and relocation applications. 
The commission shall have the authority to grant or deny a certificate of appropriateness to demolish or relocate a structure within a historic district, or on a historic property. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. V, § 135) 
Sec. 24-85. - Considerations of post-demolition plans. 
The commission shall not grant a certificate of appropriateness for demolition or relocation without reviewing at the same time the plans for the building or other development that would replace the structure. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. V, § 136) 
Sec. 24-86. - Demolition or relocation criteria. 
(a)  The commission shall evaluate the effect the demolition or relocation of a building will have on the historical character of the historic district or historic property affected. If the commission determines that demolition or relocation would have a negative effect, it will deny the certificate of appropriateness unless: 
(1)  The building in question is shown to be incapable of earning an economic return on its value after rehabilitation as determined by the commission with the advice of a qualified real estate appraiser. 
(2)  The building in question is classified as an intrusion. 
(3)  In the case of a nonprofit organization, that organization can prove that the structure cannot be successfully rehabilitated and used by the organization. 
(b)  Whenever a property owner shows that a building is incapable of earning an economic return on its value, or be successfully rehabilitated or used, such building may be demolished or relocated; provided, however, that the issuance of a certificate of appropriateness shall be subject to a delay of demolition or relocation and that notice of the proposed demolition or relocation shall be given as follows: 
(1)  For a buildings rated historic: 12-month delay. 
(2)  For a buildings rated non-historic: six-month delay. 
(3)  For a buildings intrusion: no delay. 
(c)  Notice shall be posted on the premises of the building or structure proposed for demolition in a location clearly visible from the street. In addition, notice shall be published in a newspaper or general local circulation at least three times prior to the date of the permit and the first notice of which shall be published no more than 15 days after the application for a permit to demolish is filed. The purpose of this section is to further the purpose of this chapter by preserving historic buildings which are important to the education, culture, traditions, and the economic values of the county, to allow interested persons, historical societies, or organizations the opportunity to acquire or to arrange for the preservation of such buildings. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. V, § 137) 
Sec. 24-87. - Emergency demolition permits. 
In the event the building official determines that a landmark or existing building in a historic district poses immediate threat to the safety of the community, he may request an emergency meeting of the commission. At such times the commission may authorize the emergency demolition of such structures. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. V, § 138) 
Secs. 24-88—24-103. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MAINTENANCE OF PROPERTY WITHIN THE JURISDICTION OF THE COMMISSION 

Sec. 24-104. - Ordinary repairs. 
Ordinary maintenance or repair of any exterior architectural feature in or on an existing building that does not involve a material change in design, material, or outer appearance thereof, is excluded from review. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. VI, § 139) 
Sec. 24-105. - Conformity to existing building codes. 
Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as to exempt property owners from complying with existing county building codes, nor to prevent any property owner from making any use of their property not prohibited by other statutes, ordinances or regulations. 
(Ord. of 5-14-1993, art. VI, § 140) 
Sec. 24-106. - Elimination of local districts. 
The board of commissioners shall have the authority to modify or remove any local district without a resolution or request from the historic preservation commission. Any action taken by the board of commissioners relative to the districts shall be taken by ordinance. 
Chapter 26 - MANUFACTURED HOMES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Standards and requirements for construction, installation, and licensing of manufactured homes and mobile homes, O.C.G.A. §§ 8-2-110 et seq., 8-2-130 et seq., and 8-2-160 et seq. 

Sec. 26-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Certificate of permanent location means a certificate properly obtained and filed with the clerk of superior court, as required by O.C.G.A. § 8-2-182. 
Certificate of removal from permanent location means a certificate properly obtained and filed, as required by O.C.G.A. § 8-2-184. 
Chief appraiser means the chief appraiser and any member of the appraisal staff in the office of tax assessors of the county. 
Clerk of superior court means the clerk of superior court of McIntosh County. 
Decal means the mobile home location permit obtainable from the tax commissioner and referred to in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-492. 
Home means a manufactured home or mobile home, but shall not include a home for which a certificate of permanent location has issued and been properly filed and shall not include any other home which is exempt from the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 48-5-492. 
Magistrate court means the magistrate court of the county. 
Manufactured home means a new or used structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and/or electrical systems contained therein; such term also has the meaning specified in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-160(4). 
Manufactured home statute refers to the ad valorem taxation of motor vehicles and mobile homes, article 10, title 48, chapter 5 (O.C.G.A. § 48-5-440 et seq.). 
Mobile home means a new or used structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and/or electrical systems contained therein; such term also has the meaning specified in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-160(6). 
Owner means a person or an entity, other than a lien holder or security interest holder, having an interest in a home or being named on a title as an owner of a home. Such term shall also include the person or entity which leases a home. The term "owner" also has the meaning specified in O.C.G.A. § 40-2-21. 
(Ord. of 7-10-2007(1), intro. 4) 
Sec. 26-2. - Penalties. 
Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person or entity convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-5-440 et seq. Each day a home owner is in violation of O.C.G.A. § 48-5-492 shall constitute a separate offense. The remedies and penalties stated in this chapter shall be in addition to the remedies and penalties stated in O.C.G.A. § 48-5-451. 
(Ord. of 7-10-2007(1), § 7) 
Sec. 26-3. - Adoption by reference. 
The ad valorem taxation of motor vehicles and mobile homes, article 10, title 48, chapter 5 (O.C.G.A. § 48-5-440 et seq.) is hereby adopted as an ordinance of the county with the effect as if restated herein verbatim. 
(Ord. of 7-10-2007(1), § 1) 
Sec. 26-4. - Display of decal. 
The owner of any home shall display the decal on the exterior portion of the home. Such display of decal shall be on the side of the home facing the nearest public roadway. If the home is not visible from a public roadway, then such decal shall be displayed on the side of the home facing the driveway which leads to or near the home. 
(Ord. of 7-10-2007(1), § 2) 
Sec. 26-5. - Enforcement. 
The chief appraiser of the county may enforce this chapter by issuance of a citation furnished by the board or by any other written means which complies with O.C.G.A. § 15-10-63, together with a notice informing the owner of the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 48-5-492 and state department of revenue Rule No. 560-11-9-.05. The citation shall require the owner to appear in person before the magistrate court at a certain time and date, which date shall be not earlier than 15 days nor more than 30 days from the date the citation is issued to the owner. If the name of the owner is not known to the chief appraiser, then such notice and citation shall issue to the occupant of the home. 
(Ord. of 7-10-2007(1), § 3) 
Sec. 26-6. - Owner to notify chief appraiser. 
The owner of any home which has obtained a certificate of removal from permanent location shall promptly notify the chief appraiser and the office of tax assessors of such certificate. 
(Ord. of 7-10-2007(1), § 4) 
Sec. 26-7. - Prosecution. 
This chapter may be prosecuted in the magistrate court, pursuant to article 4, title 15, chapter 10 (O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq.). 
(Ord. of 7-10-2007(1), § 5) 
Sec. 26-8. - Violation. 
Violations of this chapter may be prosecuted by the county attorney or by the chief appraiser. 
(Ord. of 7-10-2007(1), § 6) 
Chapter 28 - NUISANCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— County authority to prohibit public and private littering, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-42 et seq.; counties have the power to enforce, prevent, and punish violations of the state nuisance abatement laws, in addition to any provisions of its own local enabling act, charter, or local ordinances or regulations for the abatement of nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 28-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Building regulations means and includes the building regulations and standard codes heretofore adopted by the county, building regulations in effect in the county prior to such date, and fire regulations in effect in the county. 
Closing means securing and causing a dwelling, building, or structure to be vacated. 
County health officer or official means the official representatives of the county health department charged with the responsibility of inspecting and reviewing health and environmental matters throughout the county, which includes, but is not limited to, issues deemed nuisances under state law, the provisions of this chapter, or the ordinances of the county. 
Dwelling, building, or structure means any building or structure or part thereof used and occupied for human habitation, commercial, industrial, or business uses or intended to be so used and includes any outhouses and appurtenances belonging thereto or usually enjoyed therewith and also includes any building or structure of any design. 
Nuisance means anything that causes hurt, inconvenience, or damage to another, and the fact that the act done may otherwise be lawful shall not keep it from being a nuisance. The inconvenience complained of shall not be fanciful, or such as would affect only one of fastidious taste, but it shall be such as would affect an ordinary, reasonable person. 
Owner means the holder of the title in fee simple and every mortgagee of record. 
Parties in interest means persons in possession of a dwelling, building or structure and all individuals, association, and corporations who have interest of record in such dwelling, building or structure, including executors, administrators, guardians, and trustees. 
Public officer means the building inspector, code enforcement officer, county manager, or any other county official who is authorized by law and this Code to exercise the powers prescribed by this chapter, or any agent of such officer or officers, or any other officer or officers designated by the county manager for purposes of this chapter. 
Repair means closing a dwelling, building, or structure or the cleaning or removal of debris, trash, and other materials present and accumulated which create a health or safety hazard in or about any dwelling, building, or structure. 
Unfit building means any dwelling, building, or structure described as follows: 
(1)  Any building which is in violation of any of the provisions of the building, fire, health, sanitation or life safety code, regulation, or ordinance; 
(2)  Any building in which a loadbearing wall or other vertical structural member lists, leans or buckles to such extent as to weaken the structural support of such wall or member below the minimum required by the building regulations; 
(3)  Any building having an improperly distributed load on the floor or roof or some portion thereof; 
(4)  Any building in which there is damage or deterioration of 33 percent or more of the supporting members or 50 percent or more of the nonsupporting enclosing or outside walls, exclusive of the foundation; 
(5)  Any building with any part thereof so attached as to create a danger that it will fall or cause injury to person or property; 
(6)  Any building which is so dilapidated, decayed, deteriorated, or damaged from any cause or in any manner as to create a danger of injury to person or property; 
(7)  Any building likely to cause injury to person or property because it contains a weakened, defective, or deteriorated footing, foundation, flooring, floor support, ceiling, ceiling support, roof, or chimney; 
(8)  Any building which has visible soil erosion adjacent to or under any structural support; 
(9)  Any building in which any means of egress or portion thereof, including, for example, but not limited to, fire doors, closing devices, stairways, or fire escapes, is in disrepair or is in a dilapidated or nonworking condition or not of adequate size or is not arranged to provide a safe path of travel in case of fire or panic; 
(10)  Any building in which there exists any of the general conditions itemized in O.C.G.A. § 41-2-10; or 
(11)  Any building where there is the improper keeping of pets and animals on the premises, and/or the improper disposal of human and/or animal wastes. 
Sec. 28-2. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-9. 
(b)  Action pursuant to subsection (a) of this section shall not be a bar to enforcement of this chapter by injunction or other appropriate remedy, and the code enforcement officer shall have the power to institute and maintain in the name of the county any and all such enforcement proceedings. 
(c)  Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to abridge, limit, or otherwise impair the right of any person to maintain any action or other appropriate proceeding for damages or other relief on account of injuries to persons or property. 
Sec. 28-3. - Working with other officers. 
The county code enforcement officer shall have the authority to work in conjunction with and rely upon the advice, expertise or recommendation of the county health officer, regarding the inspection and review of issues throughout the county deemed nuisances under state law, the provisions of this chapter, or the ordinances of the county. This authority shall include the ability to issue summons or citations for violations of and to enforce the provisions of this chapter, based upon a complaint received from the county health official. 
Secs. 28-4—28-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - UNFIT BUILDINGS OR STRUCTURES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— County may adopt ordinances requiring the repair, closing, or demolition of dwellings or other structures intended for human habitation which are unfit or imperil the health, safety, or morals of the community, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-11. 

Sec. 28-25. - Structures. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, operate, create, perform or maintain, after notice, any structure or activity in the county which constitutes a public nuisance or to do or perform any activity expressly declared in any of the ordinances of the county to be a nuisance per se; and upon conviction thereof in the magistrate court, such offender shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-9. 
Secs. 28-26—28-53. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PROCEDURES FOR ABATEMENT 

Sec. 28-54. - Abatement of nuisances. 
The magistrate court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine the question of the existence of nuisances alleged to exist in the county, and if a nuisance is found to exist, to order its abatement. 
Sec. 28-55. - Procedure for abatement of public nuisances. 
(a)  Investigation and notice of complaint. Upon recommendation of the board of health or the health officer, police officer or employee of the county charged with enforcing the ordinances of the county, or the complaint of any resident of the county in writing, as to the existence of anything in the county constituting a public nuisance, the public officer charged with enforcing the provisions of this chapter shall make an investigation or inspection of the specific nuisance. If the public officer's investigation or inspection identifies circumstances constituting a nuisance, then the public officer or county attorney shall cause a written notice of the complaint setting out the alleged nuisance to be drawn up and served on the person alleged to be responsible for the nuisance and the owner of the property where the nuisance is alleged to exist, in accordance with the further provisions hereof. For the purpose of this chapter, the person returning such lot for county taxes for the year in which notice is given shall be taken to be the owner thereof. 
(b)  Time-frame for response. The notice shall be directed to the person alleged to be maintaining, erecting, creating or keeping the alleged nuisance and to the owner of the property where the nuisance is alleged to exist; shall set out facts sufficient to show the nature of the alleged nuisance; identify the subject real property where the nuisance is located by appropriate street address and official tax map reference; contain a statement of the action sought by the public officer to abate the alleged nuisance, and shall give the person to whom the notice is directed notice to abate the nuisance within not more than 30 days from the date of service of the notice or to show cause before the county court at a date and time stated, which date shall be not less than 30 days nor more than 45 days after the filing of said complaint in the magistrate court, why said alleged nuisance should not be abated. The notice here provided for shall bear teste in the name of the magistrate or his designee and be signed by the county clerk. A copy of the notice shall be served instanter upon each person to whom it is directed. 
(c)  Service of notice. The method of service of the notice above provided for shall be as follows: 
(1)  If the person to be served is a resident of the county, by personal service by any constable of the county. 
(2)  If the person to be served is a nonresident of the county but is a resident of the state, by personal service by any officer of the state authorized to serve process in civil cases under the Georgia Civil Practice Act (O.C.G.A. § 9-11-1 et seq.). 
(3)  If the person to be served is a nonresident of the state, by publication of the notice once a week for two consecutive weeks in a newspaper in which the sheriff of the county publishes its legal notices. If the address of the person to be served is known, the clerk of the county shall mail a copy of the notice, as given to the publisher, to the person to be served at his known address within three days of the first publication of the notice. In the case of service by publication, the date of the newspaper in which the last publication appears shall be considered the date of service and the date required for abatement or appearance shall be not less than five days from the date of such newspaper. 
Sec. 28-56. - Proceedings in the magistrate court. 
(a)  Judicial hearing. On the date and at the time set for the hearing before the county court, or as soon thereafter as the case can be reached for trial, the judge of the county court shall hear and determine the question of whether or not a nuisance exists and whether or not the same has been abated as required by the notice and shall make such further order as may be required by the circumstances under the further provisions hereof. 
(b)  Presentation of witnesses and evidence. The code enforcement officer or county attorney shall be responsible for presenting the case on behalf of the citizens by proper witnesses and evidence. The person charged with the nuisance shall be entitled to present witnesses and other evidence as allowed by law. 
(c)  Judicial order. If after hearing the evidence the acts complained of shall be adjudged a nuisance, the judge of the magistrate court shall issue an order upon the interested parties that have answered the complaint or appeared at the hearing, stating either of the following: 
(1)  If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building, or structure can be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to repair, alter, or improve such dwelling, building, or structure so as to bring it into full compliance with the applicable codes relevant to the cited violation and, if applicable, to secure the structure so that it cannot be used in connection with the commission of drug crimes; 
(2)  If the repair, alteration, or improvement of the said dwelling, building, or structure in order to bring it into full compliance with applicable codes relevant to the cited violations cannot be made at a reasonable cost in relation to the present value of the dwelling, building, or structure, requiring the owner, within the time specified in the order, to demolish and remove such dwelling, building, or structure and all debris from the property; or 
(3)  If abatement of the adjudged nuisance does not involve the above circumstances, then abatement of the same within a reasonable time as set by the court. 
(d)  Failure to comply. If the owner or parties in interest fail to comply with an order to abate the nuisance, or vacate and close or demolish the dwelling, building or structure, and do not seek an injunction under O.C.G.A. § 41-2-13, the code enforcement officer may cause such nuisance to be removed or such dwelling, building or structure to be repaired, altered or improved or to be vacated and closed or demolished; and the public officer may cause to be posted on the main entrance of any building, dwelling or structure so closed a placard with the following words: 
"This building is unfit for human habitation or commercial, industrial, or business use; the use or occupation of this building for human habitation or for commercial, industrial or business use is prohibited and unlawful." 
The amount of the cost of removing the nuisance or demolition in general, including all court costs, appraisal fees, and all other costs necessarily associated with the abatement action, including restoration to grade of the real property after demolition, shall be a lien against the real property upon which such cost was incurred. 
Sec. 28-57. - Other procedure for abatement of nuisances. 
Notwithstanding the provisions of sections 28-1, 28-2, 28-25, 28-54, and 28-55, where a nuisance complained of consists of acts expressly declared to be unlawful and to constitute nuisances under any other ordinance of the county, proceedings in the magistrate court may be by summons as for the violation of any county ordinance, and upon conviction in the magistrate court, the person convicted shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-9. 
Secs. 28-58—28-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ABANDONMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— County authorized to enact ordinances for removal of vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4; abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq. 

Sec. 28-90. - Definition. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Disabled, wrecked, junked, or abandoned motor vehicle means any motor vehicle which does not have lawfully affixed thereto an unexpired license plate or plates, and the condition of which is wrecked, dismantled, partially dismantled, inoperative, or discarded. 
Sec. 28-91. - Prohibited conduct. 
No person shall park, store, place, or allow to remain on the public streets, alleys, or other public places in the county, or in the open upon private property, unless necessary for operation of a business enterprise lawfully situated upon such private property, any disabled, wrecked, junked, or abandoned motor vehicle or parts of motor vehicles, or other major appliances, machinery or other junked objects, and the parking, storing, placing, or allowing to remain upon such designated places of such disabled, wrecked, junked, or abandoned property is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
Sec. 28-92. - Enforcement; notification and hearing; impoundment. 
(a)  Removal and impoundment of vehicles, etc. The county manager or code enforcement officer is authorized to tow away or cause to be towed away or removed any disabled, wrecked, junked, or abandoned motor vehicle or parts of motor vehicles or other major appliances, machinery, or other junked objects found on the public streets, alleys, or other public places within the county in violation of section 28-91, and to store and impound the same until the expenses of towing and storage shall be paid by the owner of such property. The expense of such towing and storage shall be paid by the owner of such property and such expenses may be assessed against such owner and collected as county taxes are assessed and collected. 
(b)  Notification to remove. Upon notice of the presence in the open on any private property within the county of any disabled, wrecked, junked, or abandoned motor vehicle or parts of motor vehicles or other major appliances, machinery, or other junked objects in violation of section 28-91, except where necessary in the operation of a business enterprise lawfully situated upon such property, the county manager or code enforcement officer shall at once notify the owner of such premises in writing to relocate such property to an enclosed garage or other building or to remove same from the premises. 
(c)  Failure to comply. Upon the failure of any person to relocate or remove such disabled, wrecked, junked, or abandoned property after notice as provided under state law, the code enforcement officer shall report such failure to the county manager. Upon knowledge of the failure of the person to correct the nuisance within the given period of time, the county manager may then issue a summons or direct the county attorney to issue a summons to the offending property owner requiring him to be and appear before the magistrate court to show cause why the existence of such condition on his property should not be abated as a nuisance, as provided under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5. 
(d)  Abatement by authorities; expenses assessed against owner. After such notice and hearing thereon, the county manager may properly order the abatement of such nuisance, which order shall be directed to and executed by the county manager, constable or sheriff, and such order shall include the right to impound and tow away or otherwise remove or destroy the offending property. All of the expenses of the abatement of such nuisance may be assessed against the owner of the property upon which the nuisance was located and may be collected as county taxes are assessed and collected. 
Sec. 28-93. - Sale and proceeds. 
(a)  Sale of impounded property. The owner of any property impounded under the provisions of this article shall have 30 days from the date the same was impounded to redeem the same by paying the cost of removal and storage. After 30 days from the date of the impounding of any property under the terms hereof, the constable, or his designee, may sell or otherwise dispose of the same in accordance with the procedures in O.C.G.A. § 9-13-140 et seq. and after giving opportunity for competitive bidding. 
(b)  Advance notice to be given. Notice by mail shall be sent at least ten days prior to such disposition to the registered owner of the vehicle, if known, and also to the owner or occupant of the private property from which the vehicle was removed. 
(c)  Details of notice. The notice of the sale shall state: 
(1)  The sale is of abandoned property in the possession of the county; 
(2)  A description of the vehicle, including make, model, license number and any other information which will accurately identify that vehicle; 
(3)  The terms of the sale; 
(4)  The date, time, and place of the sale; and 
(5)  Any other information required by state law. 
(d)  Disposition of proceeds. The proceeds of such sale shall be applied first to pay the expenses of sale, towing, removal, and storage, and the balance, if any, paid to the owner of the property, if known. If the owner of such property is not known, then the balance of such proceeds, if any, shall be paid into the county treasury. 
Secs. 28-94—28-114. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - AIR QUALITY CONTROL[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Georgia Air Quality Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-9-1 et seq. 

Sec. 28-115. - Emissions of gases, vapors, and odors. 
(a)  No person shall cause, suffer, or allow any emissions of gases, vapors, or odors beyond the property line from which such emissions occur to be in sufficient quantities and of such characteristics and duration as is or is likely to be injurious to the public welfare; to the health of human, plant, or animal life; or to property; or which interfere with the enjoyment of life and property. 
(b)  Detectable odors emitted from the following sources of emission are hereby declared to be objectionable, provided, however, that this listing shall not be deemed as exclusive: 
(1)  Ammonia, bleaching powder, or chlorine manufacture; 
(2)  Asphalt manufacture or refining; 
(3)  Blood processing; 
(4)  Bag cleaning; 
(5)  Celluloid manufacture; 
(6)  Coal tar products manufacture; 
(7)  Compost heaps; 
(8)  Crematory; 
(9)  Creosote treatment or manufacture; 
(10)  Disinfectants manufacture; 
(11)  Distillation of bones, coal, or wood; 
(12)  Dyestuff manufacture; 
(13)  Fat rendering; 
(14)  Fertilizer manufacture and bone grinding; 
(15)  Glue or gelatin manufacture; 
(16)  Incineration or reduction of garbage, dead animals, offal, or refuse; 
(17)  Oiled rubber or leather goods manufacture; 
(18)  Paint, oil, shellac, turpentine, or varnish manufacture; 
(19)  Paper and pulp manufacture; 
(20)  Rubber or gutta percha manufacture; 
(21)  Sauerkraut manufacture; 
(22)  Seafood processing; 
(23)  Shoe-blackening manufacture; 
(24)  Soap manufacture; 
(25)  Stockyards; 
(26)  Sulfuric, nitric, or hydrochloric acid manufacture; 
(27)  Tanning, curing, or storage of hides or skins; 
(28)  Tar distillation or manufacture; 
(29)  Tar roofing or waterproofing manufacture; and 
(30)  Any other air contaminant discharged into open air of a character and in a quantity which is detrimental to or endangers the public health. 
Sec. 28-116. - Open burning. 
(a)  Generally. Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, no person shall kindle an open fire in any public or private place outside any building. Fires started in violation of this section shall be promptly extinguished by the person responsible for same upon notice by the fire chief or his duly designated agent. During the existence of an air pollution alert, as may be declared by the county manager, all exceptions are void and no open fires shall be kindled. 
(b)  Exceptions. 
(1)  Open burning may be done under permit as follows: 
a.  Application for burning permits shall be on forms provided by the fire chief; 
b.  No permit shall be issued unless the issuing officer is satisfied that: 
1.  There is no practical available alternate method for the disposal of the material to be burned; 
2.  No hazardous condition will be created by such burning; 
3.  No salvage operation by open burning will be conducted; and 
4.  No leaves will be burned in those areas where provision is made for public collection thereof; 
c.  Any permit issued may be limited by the imposition of conditions to: 
1.  Prevent the creation of excessive smoke; or 
2.  Protect property and the health, safety, and comfort of persons from the effects of the burning; 
d.  If it becomes apparent at any time to the fire chief that limitations need to be imposed for any of the reasons stated in subsection (b)(1)c of this section, the fire chief or his duly designated agent shall notify the permittee in writing and any limitations so imposed shall be treated as conditions under which the permit is issued. 
(2)  Open burning may be done without permit as follows: 
a.  In those areas where provision for public collection of leaves is not made, the opening burning of leaves is permitted; 
b.  In those areas where regular refuse collection is not provided, open burning of ordinary household trash by householders is permitted, provided that: 
1.  The fires are located no closer than 500 feet to any neighboring habitable dwelling or place where people work or congregate;
