On any new profession, trade or calling begun in the county on or after July 1 in any year, the business or occupation tax for the remaining portion of the year shall be 50 percent of the tax imposed for the entire year. 
(Ord. of 1-9-1996, § 1-10) 
Sec. 38-144. - Registration issued by county clerk. 
The registration herein provided for shall be issued by the clerk of county commission, and if any person, firm, or corporation whose duty it is to obtain a registration shall, after said occupation tax becomes delinquent, transact or offer to transact, in the county, any of the kind of business, trade, profession, or occupation without having first obtained said registration, such offender shall be subject to the penalties provided thereof. 
(Ord. of 1-9-1996, § 1-15) 
Sec. 38-145. - Exemptions. 
The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this article but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the state or by local law: 
(1)  Those businesses regulated by the state public service commission. 
(2)  Those electrical service business organized under chapter 3 of the title 46 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated (O.C.G.A. § 46-3-1 et seq.). 
(3)  Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. 
(4)  Cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. 
(5)  Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8 et seq. 
(6)  Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. 
(7)  Those business governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355. (Businesses that purchase carload lots of guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed mean and hulls.) 
(8)  Agricultural products and livestock raised in the state governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. 
(9)  Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. 
(10)  Facilities operated by a charitable trust governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-13-55. 
(Ord. of 1-9-1996, § 1-17) 
Sec. 38-146. - Gross receipts. 
An occupation tax shall not apply to the gross receipts of any part of a business where such levy is prohibited or exempted by the laws of the state or of the United States. 
(Ord. of 1-9-1996, § 1-18) 
Sec. 38-147. - Discount. 
The taxpayer may have the following options as to payment of said tax: If the entire amount of the occupation tax is paid on or before the due date, the taxpayer shall be entitled to a ten percent discount of the amount of tax so paid allowable at the time of such payment. No discount shall be allowed for any payment made after the due date. 
(Ord. of 1-9-1996, § 1-19) 
Sec. 38-148. - Registration. 
Where a business is operated at more than one place or where the business includes more than one line, said business shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for each location and line and pay an occupation tax in accordance with the prevailing taxing method and tax rate for each location and line. 
(Ord. of 1-9-1996, § 1-20) 
Sec. 38-149. - Failure to pay. 
Except to the extent otherwise provided for in this article, upon the failure of any business to pay said occupation tax or any part thereof before it becomes delinquent, or upon failure to make any of said returns within the time required herein, or upon failure to make a true return, or upon failure to amend a return to set forth the truth, or upon failure to permit inspection of its books, as provided in this article, any business tax registration granted by the county under this article permitting the owner of said business to do business for the current year shall be, ipso facto, revoked. No new business tax registration shall be granted by the county for the operation of a business for which any part of the occupation tax herein provided for is at that time unpaid. In the case of those practitioners where the local government cannot suspend the right of the practitioner to conduct business, the imposition of civil penalties shall be permitted and pursued by the local government in the case of delinquent occupation tax. 
(Ord. of 1-9-1996, § 1-21) 
Sec. 38-150. - Effect of failure to comply with article; continuing in business after tax registration revoked. 
Any persons, their managers, agents, or employees, who do business in the county after the registration for said business has been revoked are hereby required to make occupation tax returns, and who fail to make said returns within the time and in the manner herein provided, who refuse to amend such returns so as to set forth the truth, or who shall make false returns; and any persons, their managers, agents, or employees who refuse to permit an inspection of books in their charge when the officers, agents, employees, or representatives of the county request such inspection, during business hours, for the purpose of determining the accuracy of the returns herein provided for, shall be subject to penalties provided herein. In the case of those practitioners where the local government cannot suspend the right of the practitioner to conduct business, the imposition of civil penalties shall be permitted and pursued by the local government in the case of delinquent occupation tax. These penalties may consist of either percentage of the amount due or a flat fee fine. 
(Ord. of 1-9-1996, § 1-22) 
Sec. 38-151. - Public hearing. 
The commission shall conduct at least one public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the rate of occupation tax as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. of 1-9-1996, § 1-26) 
Chapter 40 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Local powers of county regarding uniform rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 40-1. - Adoption of uniform rules of the road. 
(a)  Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-370 40-6-372—40-6-376, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-1—40-6-395, known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, and the definitions in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1, are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the county with like effect as if recited in this chapter. 
(b)  Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished according to the provisions of the general penalties described in section 1-9, but in no event shall such penalties exceed those provided by state law. 
State Law reference— Adoption of uniform rules of the road by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372. 
Secs. 40-2—40-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate or prohibit stopping, standing or parking, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(1); stopping, standing and parking generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-200 et seq. 

Sec. 40-21. - Parking at Blue-N-Hall County Park. 
(a)  A one-hour maximum limit on the parking of boats with vehicles, and a 24-hour maximum limit on the parking of vehicles with empty trailers, as well as a one hour maximum limit on the parking of vehicles without trailers or boats is hereby established for the parking areas in and adjacent to Blue-N-Hall County Park. 
(b)  Violations of the parking limitation set forth in subsection (a) of this section are to be considered misdemeanor infractions, punishable according to the general penalties described in section 1-9. A new violation shall be cited for every 24 hours that the vehicle and/or trailer/boat remains in violation. 
(Ord. of 8-17-1999) 
Secs. 40-22—40-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LOW-SPEED VEHICLES 

Sec. 40-46. - Authority; name. 
This article shall be referred to as the "Motorized Cart Control Ordinance of McIntosh County." 
(Ord. of 7-11-2006, § 2-5-1) 
Sec. 40-47. - Findings; definitions. 
(a)  The county commission finds that all streets and paved recreational paths located within the territorial boundaries of the county and under its jurisdiction are designed and constructed so as to safely permit their use by operators of motorized carts, electric bicycles, and low speed motor vehicle ("LSMV"), except as stated elsewhere in this article. 
(b)  Words and phrases used in this article shall have the following meanings, unless otherwise specified: 
All-terrain vehicle means any motorized vehicle designed for off-road use which is equipped with three or more low-pressure tires and with a seat to be straddled by the operator and with handlebars for steering control. 
Bicycle means every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having only two wheels which are in tandem and either of which is more than 13 inches in diameter. 
Dealer means a person engaged in the business of buying, selling, or exchanging vehicles who has an established place of business in this state. 
Electric bicycle means a device with two or three wheels which has a saddle and fully operative pedals for human propulsion and also has an electric motor. For such a device to be considered an electric-assisted bicycle, it shall meet the requirements of the federal motor vehicle safety standards, as set forth in 49 CFR 571 et seq., and shall operate in such a manner that the electric motor disengages or ceases to function when the brakes are applied. The electric motor in an electric assisted bicycle shall: 
(1)  Have a power output of not more than 1,000 watts; 
(2)  Be incapable of propelling the device at a speed of more than 20 miles per hour on level ground; and 
(3)  Be incapable of further increasing the speed of the device when human power alone is used to propel the device at or more than 20 miles per hour. 
Electric personal assistive mobility device or EPAMD means a self-balancing, two non-tandem-wheeled device designed to transport only one person and having an electric propulsion system with average power of 750 watts (one horsepower) and a maximum speed of less than 20 miles per hour on a paved level surface when powered solely by such propulsion system and ridden by an operator who weighs not more than 170 pounds. 
Gross weight means the weight of a vehicle without load plus the weight of any load thereon. 
Low-speed motor vehicle or LSMV means any four-wheeled electric vehicle whose top speed attainable in one mile is greater than 20 miles per hour but not greater than 25 miles per hour on a paved level surface and which is manufactured in compliance with those federal motor vehicle safety standards for low-speed vehicles set forth in 49 CFR 571.500 and in effect on January 1, 2001. 
Moped means a motor-driven cycle equipped with two or three wheels, with or without foot pedals to permit muscular propulsion, and an independent power source providing a maximum of two brake horsepower. If a combustion engine is used, the maximum piston or rotor displacement shall be 3.05 cubic inches (50 centimeters) regardless of the number of chambers in such power source. The power source shall be capable of propelling the vehicle, unassisted, at a speed not to exceed 30 miles per hour (48.28 kilometers per hour) on level road surface and shall be equipped with a power drive system that functions directly or automatically only, not requiring clutching or shifting by the operator after the drive system is engaged. 
Motorcycle means every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor, all-terrain vehicle, dirt bike, and moped. 
Motor-driven cycle means every motorcycle, including every motor scooter, with a motor which produces not to exceed five brake horsepower, every bicycle with a motor attached, and every moped. 
Motorized cart means every motor vehicle having no less than three wheels and an unladen weight of 1,300 pounds or less and which cannot operate at more than 20 miles per hour. 
Motorized play vehicle means a coaster, scooter, pocket bike, any other alternatively fueled device, or other motorized vehicle that is self-propelled by a motor engine, gas or electric, and is not otherwise defined in this Code as a "motorized cart," "low speed motor vehicle (LSMV)," "motor vehicle," "motorcycle," "electric bicycle," motorized skateboard," "electric personal assistive mobility device," or "motorized wheelchair." 
Motorized skateboard means a self-propelled device, including Segways, that has a motor, gas or electric, a deck upon which a person may ride, not equipped with a seat, and at least two tandem wheels in contact with the ground and which is not otherwise defined in this Code as a motor vehicle," "motorcycle," "motorized play vehicle," "motor scooter," "electric personal assistive mobility device" or "motorized wheelchair." 
Motorized wheelchair means a self-propelled wheelchair that is used by a physically disabled person for mobility. 
Pocket motorcycle or pocket bike means a two-wheeled vehicle other than a motor vehicle, bicycle with helper motor or a motorized scooter, and which is propelled by an internal combustion engine, electric motor or other mechanical means, is capable of carrying a rider and/or passenger at a speed in excess of 20 miles per hour, and is designed to replicate the general appearance of a motorcycle, regardless of the scale of the replication. 
(Ord. of 7-11-2006, § 2-5-2) 
Sec. 40-48. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates the terms of this article, except section 40-50(b), (c) or (d), shall be punished as provided in section 40-56; except that any fine for a littering offense shall be doubled. 
(b)  Any violation of section 40-50(b), (c) or (d) shall be charged against the registered owner of the motorized cart, and all fines and penalties shall be levied against the registered owner of he motorized cart as follows: 
(1)  For the first offense, a fine of not less than $250.00. 
(2)  For the second offense, a fine of not less than $500.00. 
(3)  For a third offense committed within one year of conviction for a second offense for a motorized cart, a fine of $1,000.00, and the registered owner's motorized cart registration shall be revoked. The registered owner or family member cannot thereafter register a motorized cart for use in the county for a period of two years following the third conviction. 
(c)  Any violation by an operator of a LSMV shall be charged against the operator according to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 et seq. and this Code. Any violation by an owner of a LSMV shall be charged against the owner according to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 et seq. and this Code. 
(Ord. of 7-11-2006, § 2-5-9.1) 
Sec. 40-49. - Registration/transfer requirements. 
(a)  Motorized carts. It shall be the duty of every owner of an electric- or gasoline-powered motorized cart that is operated over the recreation paths and streets and those areas accessible by the public to register the cart with the county within ten business days of the date of purchase. Two numerical decals shall be issued upon registration; and a record of each motorized cart number, along with the name and address of the owner, shall be maintained by the county clerk's office. The decals must be affixed to the sides of the cart in such a manner as to be fully visible at all times. The failure to have a current registration decal on a motorized cart shall be a violation of this section and subject the owner of such cart to the penalties set forth in sections 40-53 and 40-54. 
(1)  Annual registration fee. The annual registration fee for motorized carts shall be $12.00. Such registration shall be made annually by the owner of such carts on or before September 1 of each year. Such registration shall be for the period of September 1 to the following August 30. 
(2)  Registration deadline. If the cart is not registered within ten business days of purchase, a penalty will be applied in addition to the registration fee; and the cart shall be considered an unregistered cart after the ten business-day period. 
(3)  Transfers. Upon occurrence of a sale of the cart to another person who shall operate the cart over the recreation paths and streets of the county, the registration must be transferred to the new owner within ten business days of the change in ownership and if the new owner is not a county resident, the nonresident registration/user fee for the balance of the year shall be due from the new owner. If the registration is not transferred within ten business days, a penalty will be applied in addition to the transfer charge; and the cart shall be considered an unregistered cart after the ten business-day period. Dealers acquiring a registered cart exclusively for resale (non-rental) shall not be required to pay the transfer charge, but shall notify the county of the transfer within ten business days of receiving the cart, and of the ultimate disposition of the cart within ten business days of sale. 
(4)  Special tourism events. The county board of commissioners may, at its discretion, waive registration requirements for special events of a limited duration to which out-of-county residents may bring carts as participants. 
(5)  Fees. The fees mentioned in the this section shall be established by resolution of the board of commissioners and available for public examination in the office of the county clerk. 
(b)  Gasoline carts. 
(1)  Every gasoline-powered motorized cart shall at all times be equipped with an exhaust system in good working order and in constant operation, meeting the following specifications: 
a.  The exhaust system shall include the piping leading from the flange of the exhaust manifold to and including the muffler and exhaust pipes or include any and all parts specified by the manufacturer. 
b.  The exhaust system and its elements shall be securely fastened, including the consideration of missing or broken brackets or hangers. 
c.  The engine and powered mechanism of every cart shall be so equipped, adjusted and tuned as to prevent the escape of excessive smoke or fumes. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any gasoline-powered motorized cart to operate or permit the operation of such cart on which any device controlling or abating atmospheric emissions, which is placed on a cart by the manufacturer, to render the device unserviceable by removal, alteration or which interferes with its operation. 
(c)  Rental carts. Cart dealers and distributors, as well as other commercial establishments, may rent carts to the public for use on the recreation paths and streets and those areas accessible by the public of the county. Each such establishment renting carts shall be required to register each such rental cart in accordance with subsections (a) and (b) of this section and shall maintain a written record of each person who rents each cart. Renters shall be required to furnish positive identification, shall be provided a copy of this article to read, and must be at least 16 years of age. The registration fee and transfer fees and regulations shall be the same as those in subsections (a) and (b) of this section. 
(d)  Age, number of registrants limited. Only those persons 18 years of age or older may register a motorized cart. Cart registration may be in one person's name only, and the registration form must be signed by that person. 
(e)  LSMV. No LSMV shall be operated on the paved recreational paths or streets located within the territorial boundaries of the county unless it is legally registered and insured according to laws of the state. 
(Ord. of 7-11-2006, § 2-5-3; Ord. of 9-14-2010, § 4(a)) 
Sec. 40-50. - Operation regulations. 
(a)  Those persons who are 16 years of age and older who hold a valid vehicle driver's license may drive a motorized cart on the recreation paths and/or streets and those areas accessible by the public of the county unless such person has had his license to operate a motor vehicle suspended or revoked by the state which issued said license in which case such person shall not be permitted to operate a motorized cart on the recreation paths and/or streets and those areas accessible by the public of the county during the time of suspension or revocation. 
(b)  Those persons who are 15 years of age but not yet 16 years of age may drive a motorized cart on the recreation paths and/or streets and those areas accessible by the public of the county: 
(1)  If he has in his possession a valid instructional permit issued by the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-5-24, as may be amended, and he is accompanied in the front seat by a person at least 18 years of age who holds a valid motor vehicle driver's license or he shall be accompanied in the front seat by a parent, grandparent or legal guardian who is capable of exercising control over the vehicle; or 
(2)  If he has in his possession a valid instructional permit issued by the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 40-5-24, as may be amended, and is accompanied by a licensed driver as provided in subsection (b)(1) of this section, then he may be accompanied in the vehicle by up to one other person who must be at least 15 years of age, or he may be accompanied by up to three immediate family members providing the motorized cart has seats to accommodate such persons. 
(c)  Those persons who are 12 years of age but not yet 15 years of age may drive a motorized cart on the recreation paths and/or streets and those areas accessible by the public of the county if they are accompanied in the front seat by a parent, grandparent or legal guardian. 
(d)  No person under the age of 12 shall be permitted to drive a motorized cart on the recreation paths and/or streets and those areas accessible by the public of the county under any circumstances. 
(e)  All operators shall abide by all traffic regulations applicable to vehicular traffic when using the recreation paths, streets and those areas accessible by the public in the county. Where paths exist, they must be used in preference to parallel county streets with the exclusion of those cart paths privately owned and maintained by golf courses and not used by the general public. 
(f)  Motorized cart shall not be operated on sidewalks at any time. 
(g)  Motorized carts may be operated over those authorized streets, recreational paths and those areas accessible by the public only during daylight hours unless such motorized carts are equipped with functional headlights and taillights. 
(h)  No motorized cart shall be permitted to operate over, along, or across any federal or state highway within the boundaries of the county except where authorized crossings are provided. 
(i)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any motorized cart or LSMV or any other person operating, employing, permitting the use of or otherwise directing the use of such motorized cart or LSMV to operate or permit the operator of any motorized cart or LSMV to drive over the recreational paths, streets or those areas accessible by the public in the county in violation of this article. 
(j)  Only persons possessing a valid license issued by this state, another state of the United States of America, or international agency which permits such person to operate a motor vehicle on the highways of the state may operate a LSMV on the paved recreational paths or streets located within the territorial boundaries of the county. 
(k)  No LSMV shall be permitted to operate on, over, along, or across any federal or state highway within the boundaries of the county except where authorized crossings are provided. No LSMV shall be permitted to operate on any street on which the posted speed limit exceeds 35 miles per hour. Except as prohibited in this section, LSMVs shall be permitted to cross over streets of which the posted speed limit exceeds 35 miles per hour. 
(Ord. of 7-11-2006, § 2-5-4) 
Sec. 40-51. - Recreation path users—Authorized. 
Authorized users of paved recreation paths and sidewalks are as follows: 
(1)  Pedestrians; 
(2)  Non-motorized vehicles; 
(3)  Roller skates, roller blades and skateboarders (daylight only); 
(4)  Registered electric-powered golf carts; 
(5)  Registered gasoline-powered golf carts; 
(6)  Emergency and authorized maintenance vehicles; 
(7)  Bicycles, traditional and electric (as defined in section 40-47); 
(8)  Electric and conventional wheelchairs; 
(9)  Electric vehicles designed to carry one person at a speed not to exceed 20 miles per hour except as prohibited in section 40-52; and 
(10)  LSMV, provided that the vehicle is operated only in a mode or other restriction which does not allow the vehicle to exceed 20 miles per hour. 
(Ord. of 7-11-2006, § 2-5-5) 
Sec. 40-52. - Same—Prohibited uses. 
Prohibited uses of recreation paths are as follows: 
(1)  Automobiles and trucks (except authorized maintenance vehicles); 
(2)  Motorcycles; 
(3)  Street and trail motorized bikes or vehicles (not to include electric bicycles); 
(4)  Minibikes and mopeds; 
(5)  Horses; 
(6)  Go-carts; 
(7)  Unregistered electric-powered golf carts or motorized carts; 
(8)  Unregistered gasoline-powered golf carts or motorized carts; 
(9)  Electric or gasoline powered scooters; 
(10)  Motorized play vehicles; 
(11)  Unregistered LSMVs; and 
(12)  Except as permitted in section 40-51, any vehicle designed by the manufacturer to be able to travel at speeds in excess of 20 miles per hour under its own power on a flat surface. 
(Ord. of 7-11-2006, § 2-5-6) 
Sec. 40-53. - Hazardous activities and special rules. 
(a)  Paths are for transportation and public recreation by the various groups of permitted users. No individual or group shall engage in hazardous activities on the paths and streets and those areas accessible by the public. Such hazardous activities, and the special rules pertaining to them, include but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Racing of any form, except for special events approved by the county; and 
(2)  Blocking of public access, except for special events approved by the county. 
(b)  None of the prohibited users in section 40-52 shall use the path system or the bridges and/or their underpasses for any purpose whatsoever. 
(c)  Pedestrians, skaters and permitted vehicles shall not loiter or park on recreation path bridges or in underpasses. 
(d)  Normal rules of the road shall apply to the recreation paths. For instance, when approaching oncoming path users, each user shall move to his right side of the path. Passing shall be on the left side of the path. 
(e)  Pedestrians should be given due consideration and reasonable right-of-way by other users of the recreation paths to ensure them safe passage. 
(f)  A warning or announcement shall be given by operators of golf carts and other users of the recreation paths, such as bicyclists and skaters, when approaching pedestrians from the rear. This warning or announcement may be verbal, but it is recommended that bicyclists and golf carts operators equip their vehicles with a warning device such as a horn or bell. Each user of the recreation paths shall be considerate of the safety and welfare of other users, and dangerous conduct will not be tolerated. 
(g)  All laws and ordinances relative to alcohol and its use, including open container laws, which apply to traffic on the streets of the county also apply to the recreation paths. 
(h)  All litter shall be deposited in the receptacles provided along the recreation paths or retained by the path user for proper disposal later. Littering on the recreation paths shall be subject to twice the fines and penalties as littering on the streets. 
(i)  All users of electric bicycles shall wear a properly fitted and fastened bicycle helmet which meets the standards of the American National Standards Institute or the Snell Memorial Foundation's Standards for Protective Headgear for Use in Bicycling or a motorcycle helmet while operating an electric bicycle on the recreational paths. 
(j)  No one under the age of 15 shall operate an electric bicycle on the recreational paths. 
(k)  Seat belts on LSMVs shall be worn by all occupants at all times the vehicle is moving. 
(l)  All operators and passengers must remain seated at all times during the operation of the golf cart. No person may sit on the operator's lap during the operation of the golf cart. 
(Ord. of 7-11-2006, § 2-5-7) 
Sec. 40-54. - Motorized play vehicle; authorizations; prohibitions; disclosure requirements. 
(a)  No motorized play vehicle may be operated on any public street, public roadway, public sidewalk, public park, public or private parking lot, public trail, public shared multi-use path, public bicycle path, and all other public property. 
(b)  Motorized play vehicles are permitted on private residential or rural property with the permission of the property owner. In the case of residential property commonly owned by a homeowners' association, the homeowners' association may regulate such usage. 
(c)  No motorized play vehicle may be operated on any private commercial/industrial property unless the location where the vehicles are to be operated is inaccessible to normal pedestrian or vehicular traffic (such as an enclosed warehouse or fenced parking lot with a locked gate). Motorized play vehicles may be operated on private commercial/industrial property meeting these restrictions with the written permission of the owner, the person entitled to immediate possession of the property, or the authorized agent of either. 
(d)  No person shall operate a motorized play vehicle on any private property in a manner causing excessive, unnecessary, or offensive noise which disturbs the peace and quiet of any neighborhood or which causes discomfort or annoyance to a reasonable person of normal sensitivity. 
(e)  The parent, guardian, or legal custodian of any minor shall not authorize or knowingly permit such minor to violate any of the provisions of this section. 
(f)  It is unlawful for any vendor or merchant to sell motorized play vehicles without making disclosures required by this section. Any merchant or vendor who sells motorized play vehicles within the county shall: 
(1)  Post in a prominent place at each location where motorized play vehicles are on display, a notice, on a sign not less than 96 square inches and visible to the public, stating that operation of motorized play vehicles: 
a.  Are prohibited on any public street, public roadway, public sidewalk, public park, public parking lot, public trail, public shared multi-use path, public highway or any part of a highway, public bicycle path and all other public property in the county. 
b.  Are allowed to be used on private residential or rural property with owner's written permission. 
c.  Are allowed to be used on private commercial/industrial property only in areas inaccessible to normal pedestrian or vehicular traffic and only with the written permission of the owner/agent. 
(2)  Provide a copy of such notice to each purchaser of a motorized play vehicle, either before or in connection with the purchase of a motorized play vehicle. If the purchaser is a minor, the minor's parent or legal guardian must sign a receipt of said notice. 
(3)  Any motorized play vehicle owned by a governmental entity and which is operated in the performance of authorized duties or activities, is exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(g)  Temporary suspension of all or part of this section may be granted by the county commission for special events. 
(Ord. of 7-11-2006, § 2-5-7.1) 
Sec. 40-55. - Liability. 
Each person using the recreation paths is liable for his own actions. Liability insurance coverage varies, and each person operating a golf cart or other motorized or non-motorized vehicle on the recreation paths and public streets and those areas accessible by the public should verify his coverage. 
(Ord. of 7-11-2006, § 2-5-8) 
Sec. 40-56. - Enforcement jurisdiction; general penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  Jurisdiction for the enforcement of this article shall be in the magistrate court of the county. Whenever in this article any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in this article the doing of any act is required and the failure to do such act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided, and unless otherwise provided by state law, the violation of any such provision of this article shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-9. Each day any violation of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The judge of the magistrate court shall have the power and authority to: 
(1)  Impose upon persons convicted in the magistrate court the fines provided for in this article or as otherwise provided by law, with the alternative of other punishment allowed by law, if such fines are not paid; 
(2)  Sentence such person to community service work; or 
(3)  Impose a sentence consisting of any combination of the penalties provided for in this section. 
(c)  The judge of the magistrate court shall have full power and authority to declare the forfeiture of bonds given by offenders for their appearance before the magistrate court upon the offender's failure to appear as provided for in such bond. The procedure for the forfeiture of such bonds shall be as is provided for the forfeiture of bonds and recognizance set forth in O.C.G.A. § 17-6-70 et seq. 
(d)  In the event the penalty for violation of any provision of this article shall be beyond the legal authority of the magistrate judge as provided by state law, jurisdiction for the enforcement of such violation shall be in the state court of the county. 
(Ord. of 7-11-2006, § 2-5-9) 
State Law reference— Jurisdiction of magistrate courts, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-2; violation of county ordinances, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60 et seq.; imposition of additional penalty for certain drug offenses, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-100; imposition of additional penalty for offense of driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-112; additional penalty assessments for jail construction and staffing, O.C.G.A. § 15-21-93; punishment for misdemeanors generally, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-3; deposit of drivers license for violations of laws pertaining to traffic and motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 17-6-11; payments to peace officers annuity and benefit fund from revenues collected from fines and fees, O.C.G.A. § 47-17-60 et seq.; alternative punishments for violations involving a traffic offense, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-3(e). 
Secs. 40-57—40-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - VEHICLE STORAGE 

Sec. 40-86. - Guidelines. 
In no way should a vehicle storage facility be construed as being an automotive salvage facility or junkyard. The following are minimum guidelines which must be adhered to in the operation of a vehicle storage facility: 
(1)  Such facility shall only be located in an area zoned C-G. 
(2)  Dismantling of vehicles, in whole or in part, shall be prohibited. 
(3)  Buying and/or selling of parts of vehicles in any manner shall be prohibited. 
(4)  Repairs to vehicles on the site, other than emergency repairs which may be required to get a vehicle cranked and removed, are prohibited. 
(5)  Wrecked vehicles or vehicles which are otherwise inoperable must be removed from the site within 120 days from the initial date of storage, unless requested by a law enforcement officer to keep a vehicle the site for a longer period. 
(6)  Reasonable surveillance for security purposes shall be provided by the operator of the vehicle storage facility. 
(7)  The facility shall be fenced by an opaque screen fence not less than six feet in height with three strands of barbed wire around the top of said fence, said barbed wire to be angled forward of said fence. 
(8)  Fire lanes of not less then 25 feet shall be maintained. 
(9)  Vehicles shall not be stored in a double-decked fashion. 
(Ord. of 1994, § 1) 
Chapter 42 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to provide for the development, storage and distribution of water, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(7); Georgia Water Quality Control Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-20 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 42-1—42-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER SERVICE 

Sec. 42-19. - Applicability. 
These policies apply exclusively to water and sewer systems operated and owned by McIntosh County. 
(Ord. of 5-22-1993, § I; Ord. of 4-9-2013) 
Sec. 42-20. - Authority and responsibilities. 
(a)  All authority and responsibility for enforcing these policies and procedures, of setting water fees, safe and efficient operation, maintenance, and reporting belongs to the county. 
(b)  The water and sewer department, hereinafter referred to as "county," shall run a service line from its distribution line to the property line where the distribution line exists or is to be constructed, and runs immediately adjacent and parallel to the property to be served. 
(c)  The department may make connections to service other properties not adjacent to its lines upon payment of reasonable costs for the extensions of its distribution lines as may be required to render the service. 
(d)  The county may install its meter at or near the property line or, at the department's option, on the customer's property within three feet of the property line. 
(e)  The county reserves the right to refuse service unless the customer's lines or piping are installed in such a manner as to prevent cross-connections or backflow. 
(f)  Under normal conditions the customer will be notified of any anticipated interruptions of service. Failure to notify the customer of service interruptions will not create a liability for the department. 
(g)  Duly authorized agents of the county shall have access at all hours to the premises of the customer for the purpose of installing or removing department property, inspecting piping, reading and testing meters, or for any other purpose in connection with the water service and its facilities, and the sewer service and its facilities. 
(h)  Extensions to the system shall be made only when the customer shall grant or convey, or shall cause to be granted or conveyed, to the county a permanent easement of right-of-way across any property traversed by the water or sewer lines. 
(Ord. of 5-22-1993, § II; Ord. of 4-9-2013) 
Sec. 42-21. - Standard operating procedures and duties assigned. 
The county may: 
(1)  Use public funds to extend water lines along public rights-of-way, or it may require potential water customers to share the cost, or bear the total cost. Cost for connecting to a water line and installing water service on private property is the responsibility of the property owner. 
(2)  Apply for and utilize funds which may be available for assisting eligible low-income families to install water service. 
(3)  Pay for repairs and be reimbursed over a period of time agreed to by the county and the association concerned if an emergency occurs and the association concerned does not have sufficient funds on hand to correct the situation. 
(4)  Assign public works department personnel to provide technical/engineering assistance. 
(Ord. of 5-22-1993, § III; Ord. of 4-9-2013) 
Sec. 42-22. - Water use fees. 
(a)  Operating, maintenance, and replacement costs will be paid for by the water users through monthly water fees. 
(b)  The monthly water fee for all customers on the county system shall be set by the county. 
(c)  Fees may be adjusted by the county by ordinance or resolution of the county commission. 
(d)  Customers who are more than 30 days overdue with their payment will pay an additional late charge. Service will be cut off for customers more than 60 days overdue with their payments. Water service will not be reestablished until all back fees and late charges are paid. 
(e)  There is a reconnection fee to charge all customers whose water access has been turned off. 
(f)  The late charge and reconnect fee will be established by resolution or ordinance of the board of commissioners from time to time, and available for public examination in the office of the county clerk. 
(g)  A customer who has a high monthly water bill as a result from a plumbing problem may petition the county manager for an adjustment. No customer shall be allowed more than one adjustment per 12-month period and the amount adjusted to shall be equal to a six-month average water usage by the customer. In addition, to be eligible for the adjustment, the customer must provide documentation of where said plumbing issue was resolved. For example, a bill from a plumber for services rendered would be satisfactory or receipts for supplies associated with leak. 
(Ord. of 5-22-1993, § IV; Ord. of 4-9-2013; Ord. of 6-11-2013(2)) 
Editor's note— An ordinance adopted June 11, 2013, amended § 42-22 with the addition of subsection (h); however, at the editor's discretion, said subsection has been redesignated (g) in order to preserve the sequential lettering of the subsections. 
Sec. 42-23. - Well drilling and permitting by governments located outside of McIntosh County. 
The McIntosh County Board of Commissioners reserves the right to approve or disapprove of any county, city or other government seeking to install wells or other water facilities within McIntosh County without the approval of the McIntosh County Board of Commissioners. Any approval granted shall include a fee to be determined by McIntosh County to serve as a permit fee. 
(Ord. of 4-14-2015(1)) 
Secs. 42-24—42-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER USAGE RATE 

Sec. 42-40. - Findings. 
(a)  The board of commissioners of the county has found that its citizens are desirous of the board furnishing clean drinking water, and that its citizens desire a ready supply of water in greater geographic areas than is presently available. Because the board was without sufficient funds to pay for the cost of the improvement of its water system, the board applied for and has been granted a low-interest loan and grant by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA). 
(b)  The USDA has set the minimum rate which the board must establish to fund the repayment of the low-interest loan, to wit: $29.00 for the first 1,000 gallons of water usage and $3.50 for each additional 1,000 gallons of water usage. 
(c)  The environmental protection division requires a graduated rate to foster conservation of the supply of water as a condition of new or modified withdrawal permits. 
(d)  The board finds that the water usage rate set in this article is the minimum rate necessary to fund the cost of the supply of water. 
(Ord. of 7-8-2010, § 2; Ord. of 4-9-2013) 
Sec. 42-41. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Base charge means a fee used to recover non-volume-related costs, associated with billing, meter reading, and a portion of administrative costs. The amount is the same each billing period regardless of water used by the end user and may increase based on meter size. 
Base rate means the monetary fee for the first volume block of water used by a customer in the multitiered rate structure stated in this article. 
County water system includes all wells, tanks, mains, and water lines connected to the McIntosh County water network. 
Water customer means the person and entity which applies for the provision of water from the county and those who are connected to the county water system. 
(Ord. of 7-8-2010, § 4; Ord. of 4-9-2013) 
Sec. 42-42. - Rate schedule. 
The board establishes the following rate schedule for each water customer connected to the county water system: 
(1)  Base rate/base charge. The base rate includes the base charge, which amount shall be a minimum charge of $29.00 per billing cycle (approximately monthly) per connection (i.e., per water customer). This rate shall include the first 1,000 gallons of water supplied. 
(2)  Tiered rate. 
a.  Additionally, the rate shall be $3.50 for each 1,000 gallons supplied above the base rate, for water usage up to 5,000 gallons (i.e., $3.50 for each 1,000 gallons supplied above the first 1,000 gallons up to 5,000 gallons per billing cycle). 
b.  Additionally, the rate shall be $3.75 for each 1,000 above the provision of 5,000 gallons (i.e., $3.75 for each 1,000 gallons supplied above the aforestated 5,000 gallons per billing cycle). 
(3)  These fees may be changed from time to time by resolution and such amended fee schedule shall be available at the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners. The amendment shall not be effective for a period of 30 days after the schedule is adopted by the board of commissioners. 
(4)  These fees shall pertain to the wastewater treatment facility located in Eulonia off of Highway 57. There shall be a fee of $4.00 per 1,000 gallons of treated wastewater. Wastewater shall be measured by utilizing current water meter levels. In addition, there shall be a monthly base charge of $250.00 per connection. 
(Ord. of 7-8-2010, § 5; Ord. of 4-9-2013) 
Sec. 42-43. - Tap-in fees, deposits, and fees. 
The Board herby establishes the following fees: 
(1)  Effective April 15, 2013, there shall be a mandatory deposit on new accounts of $100.00 per account. Deposit is refundable upon termination of service and can be applied toward any outstanding balances. 
(2)  There shall be a one-time administrative fee of $15.00 for all new accounts. This fee shall cover all administrative costs for the new service. 
(3)  New meter installation shall be $250.00. This fee is one time only and covers labor and materials associated with installation. 
(4)  A fee of $500.00 shall be assessed as a connection fee for new customers tying into the system. This fee shall go towards capital cost associated with the water system. 
(5)  County shall assess a fee of $50.00 to either reconnect or disconnect an account. 
(6)  All accounts delinquent shall be charged $5.00 per month late fee. Said amount is not prorated. 
(Ord. of 7-8-2010, § 6; Ord. of 4-9-2013) 
Sec. 42-44. - Mandatory tie-ins. 
(a)  A development or subdivision within 1,000 linear feet of the county public water system, its lines and easements, must tie onto the county public water system in accordance with county specifications. All costs shall be borne by the developer of the development or subdivision. 
(b)  A county resident or business within 200 linear feet of the county public water system, its lines and easements, must tie onto the county public water system in accordance with county specifications. All costs shall be borne by the customer, but nothing contained herein shall prevent the board of commissioners from waiving the costs of the hookup during the initial construction phase of the installation project. 
(Ord. of 4-19-2013) 
Sec. 42-45 - Suspension of service. 
(a)  The county reserves the right to discontinue its service without notice for any of the following additional reasons: 
(1)  To prevent fraud or abuse; 
(2)  Customer's willful disregard of departmental rules; 
(3)  Insufficiency of water supply due to circumstances beyond the department's control; 
(4)  Emergency repairs; 
(5)  Legal processes; 
(6)  Direction of public authorities; 
(7)  Strike, riot, fire, flood or unavoidable accident. 
(b)  The following is the general process by which an account shall be disconnected: 
(1)  Customer is notified that their account is past due. 
(2)  Customer does not pay balance in a timely manner as prescribed by this chapter. Customers shall be notified when their account is delinquent. When the account is more than 60 days delinquent, it is subject to disconnection by the county. 
(3)  Customer's service shall be disconnected until the balance is paid and all additional fees for disconnection and reconnection are paid. 
(4)  If customer restores service to property without paying balance and trespassing upon county-owned meter, a lock will be installed on the meter to further prevent theft and charges may be brought by the county. 
(5)  If customer removes lock, then the county will remove the meter and issue a citation to the owner or account holder for theft and damage of public property and any additional charges. 
(Ord. of 4-9-2013) 
Secs. 42-46—42-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OUTDOOR WATERING OF LANDSCAPE 

Sec. 42-60. - Restriction on outdoor watering of landscape. 
Outdoor watering for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants in the unincorporated area of the county may occur only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; provided, however, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 12-5-7(a)(1), (2), such watering time limitation shall not apply to the following outdoor water uses: 
(1)  Commercial raising, harvesting, or storing of crops; feeding, breeding, or managing livestock or poultry; the commercial production or storing of feed for use in the production of livestock, including, but not limited to, cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep, and rabbits, or for use in the production of poultry, including, but not limited to, chickens, hens, ratites, and turkeys; producing plants, trees, fowl, or animals; or the commercial production of aquacultural, horticultural, dairy, livestock, poultry, eggs, and apiarian products or as otherwise defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; 
(2)  Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable ordinances and state guidelines; 
(3)  Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations; 
(4)  Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources to provide reclaimed wastewater; 
(5)  Watering personal food gardens; 
(6)  Watering new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of 30 days immediately following the date of installation; 
(7)  Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; 
(8)  Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; 
(9)  Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; 
(10)  Watering horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; 
(11)  Watering athletic fields, golf courses, or public turf grass recreational areas; 
(12)  Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; or 
(13)  Hydroseeding. 
(Ord. of 12-14-2010(2), § 1; Ord. of 4-9-2013) 
Sec. 42-61. - Enforcement. 
(a)  No person shall use or allow the use of water in violation of the restrictions on outdoor water use contained in this article. 
(b)  The county building inspector and his assistants, any code enforcement officer, and the county sheriff and his deputies shall be the enforcement authority for this article. The county manager may also authorize other departments as may be deemed necessary to support enforcement. 
(c)  Criminal and alternative penalties. Any violation of this section may also be enforced by a citation or accusation returnable to the magistrate court or to any other court of competent jurisdiction and is punishable by a fine of up to $1,000.00. 
(Ord. of 12-14-2010(2), § 2; Ord. of 4-9-2013) 
Chapter 44 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 44-1—44-17. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WRECKER SERVICE 

Sec. 44-18. - Definitions. 
Words and phrases used in this article shall have the following meanings, unless otherwise specified: 
Motor vehicle has the meaning as that term is defined in the Official Code of Georgia Annotated. 
Wrecker service operation means any company, firm, business or individual or group of individuals for hire by the general public which provides by any means the hauling, moving or transferring from one place to another any damaged, disabled, inoperable, operable or impounded motor vehicle. 
(Res. of 8-11-1987, § 2(b), (c); Ord. of 11-14-1995, § 2; Ord. of 07-11-2017(1)) 
Sec. 44-19. - Penalty. 
Any person, firm or corporation who shall fail to comply with the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished according to the general penalties described in section 1-9. 
(Ord. of 11-14-1995, § 10; Ord. of 07-11-2017(1)) 
Sec. 44-20. - License required. 
Any wrecker service which hauls, moves or transfers motor vehicles, operable or inoperable within the unincorporated area of the county at the request or direction of the county, its employees or any law enforcement officer, shall first obtain a license to do so from the county, before engaging in such business. The fee therefore shall be set by resolution by the board of county commissioners. 
(Res. of 8-11-1987, § 1; Ord. of 11-14-1995, § 1; Ord. of 07-11-2017(1)) 
Sec. 44-21. - Application. 
Application for a license to conduct a wrecker service operation as required under this article shall be made as provided in section 44-20, except that such application shall contain the following additional information: 
(1)  Trade names used during the previous five years by the applicant and each person signing the application along with the locations of prior establishments. 
(2)  The names and addresses of the owners of such business. If such business is a corporation, the names and owners of all persons owning stock in said corporation. 
(3)  Such other information as may be prescribed from time to time by the county commissioners which in the judgment of the commissioners is needed to determine whether such person, firm, organization or individual sufficiently complies with all the requirements of this section. 
(Res. of 8-11-1987, § 3; Ord. of 11-14-1995, § 3; Ord. of 07-11-2017(1)) 
Sec. 44-22. - Requirements. 
The following operating requirements shall apply to all wrecker service operations and every item hereunder is a condition precedent to obtaining such a license and maintaining such license and the failure to abide by the requirements at all times shall be cause for revocation and/or denial of such license. 
(1)  All such wrecker service operations shall make available to the county on a 24-hour basis, every day of the year said services when and as called for non-consensual tow services at a price not more than the established maximum service fee provided in section 44-23. 
(2)  Prior to the issuance of the license required by this article and prior to the conduct of any such operations by said wrecker service, such wrecker service shall obtain and cause to be kept in force at all times during the term of any such license granted under this section, liability insurance issued by a company or companies of sound and adequate financial responsibility of the following types and minimum amounts: public liability insurance; as required by statute (federal and state) but no less than bodily injury and property damage, $500,000.00 per occurrence, single limit coverage; garage keepers legal liability insurance with limits of $100,000.00 and on the hook cargo insurance (light-duty wrecker $50,000.00; heavy-duty wrecker $100,000.00). 
(3)  Said insurance policy or policies shall name the county, as a certificate holder and such policies of liability insurance shall not thereby cause the county to be deemed a partner or joint venture with the wrecker service operator in its business. 
(4)  Such wrecker service operator shall also carry workers compensation insurance in the amounts and form required by the Workers Compensation Act and insurance laws of the state and shall furnish proof of same to the county board of commissioners, designated agent of the county for this purpose, prior to the granting of any license hereunder and from time to time upon request by said the county board of commissioners. 
(5)  Copies of the certificates of all insurance coverage required of the wrecker service shall be filed with the county, and shall provide therein that the policies of insurance referred to in such certificates shall not be subject to cancellation by the insurer except after delivery of written notice by certified mail to the county board of commissioners at least 30 days prior to the effective date of any such cancellation. 
(6)  Should the wrecker service operator fail or refuse to obtain and keep in full force and effect the insurance required by this article, the county may revoke the license provided for hereunder. 
(7)  Within the area of the county (including municipalities) the wrecker service operator shall provide an area for the storage of vehicles which have been moved, hauled or transferred by the wrecker service operator at the request of the county, its employees or any law enforcement officer. All impounded motor vehicles hauled or towed by such wrecker service shall be stored in said storage facility and an office shall be maintained at the storage area for the convenience of the public in retrieving their vehicles. This office shall be available to the public on an on-call basis 24 hours every day of the year. Such facility must be maintained properly, clean and presentable at all times and shall be subject to inspection by the county sheriff's office. Failure to properly maintain facilities shall be cause for revocation of the license granted hereunder. Further, no impounded automobile hauled, moved, retrieved or transferred from one place to another by the wrecker service operator shall be stored at any place whatsoever other than a storage area which meets the following minimum requirements: 
a.  Such storage area shall meet all county zoning requirements and ordinances pertaining to vehicle storage. 
b.  The storage area and premises shall be kept in a clean and orderly fashion. 
c.  There shall be ample space to store a minimum of 25 automobiles at the same time. The standard size automobile to be used for determining whether such storage facility meets the approval of this requirement is seven feet by 16 feet. 
(8)  Services are to be rendered immediately upon request from the county 911 central dispatcher or sheriff's office employee. The wrecker service operator shall not respond to the scene of an accident unless called to the scene by the county 911 central dispatcher or sheriff's office employee. This resolution recognizes the right of an individual who is the owner of any wrecked or impounded vehicle to select his own wrecker service company provided his state of sobriety or capacity is assured and provided that said vehicle is not blocking the roadway or otherwise dangerous to the traveling public. 
(9)  The wrecker service operator shall comply with and conform to all federal, state and local laws and/or rules and regulations, regarding safety now in effect or as new ones become applicable. The wrecker service owner must submit to a background police and general records check for prior offenses or irregularities to determine suitability, reliability and financial stability in order to properly protect the public against abuse, neglect or malfeasance. No person who has been convicted of a felony or any crime involving moral turpitude shall be granted a license pursuant to the terms of this section. 
(10)  Prior to the issuance of any license hereunder the wrecker service operator must have and demonstrate his ownership [of] one of the following types of equipment: 
a.  One each heavy-duty wrecker. A heavy-duty wrecker shall be defined as wrecker with at least 32,000 pounds minimum gross vehicle weight rating equipped with a 16 to 25 ton power take-off mechanically driven power winch crane and having independent dual booms or independent dual winches and with dual rear wheels. 
b.  One each light-duty wrecker. A light-duty wrecker shall be defined as a wrecker with at least 10,000 pounds minimum gross vehicle weight rating equipped with eight 8,000 pound power take-off, power winch, per independent boom with dual rear wheels. 
c.  One each roll back or car carrier may be substituted for one light-duty wrecker; a light-duty car carrier shall be defined as a wrecker with at least 10,000 pounds gross vehicle weight with dual rear wheels, power driven winch with complete hydraulic wrecker system. 
(11)  Each wrecker provided hereunder shall be required to carry a full complement of service items such as fire extinguishers, chains, ropes, blocks, dollies, sports car bar, motorcycle bar, stoplights, flashers, floodlights, hand tools, lock-out tools, wrecking bars, brooms, and any other tools needed for lifting, extracting, righting and removal of a [wrecked] or disabled vehicle or other equipment from public thoroughfares by towing or carting. If at any time after the granting of the license required by this article, the wrecker service operator fails to maintain the equipment required by this section such failure shall be cause for revocation of said license. All wreckers and other equipment must be inspected annually by the county sheriff's department, and any new wrecker must be inspected prior to being put in service. 
(12)  All licenses issued under this article shall be posted conspicuously in the place of business of the wreck service and in each and every heavy duty wrecker and light duty wrecker used by said operator in its wrecker services. 
(Res. of 8-11-1987, §§ 2(b), 2(c), 3(c), 4; Ord. of 11-14-1995, § 4; Ord. of 07-11-2017(1)) 
Sec. 44-23. - Fees. 
(a)  The wrecker service operator will charge the public for all services rendered at rates not greater than those set forth herein as follows: 
(1)  Light duty wrecker: $125.00 maximum per hour and $31.25 every one-fourth hour thereafter. 
(2)  Heavy duty wrecker: $250.00 maximum per hour and $62.50 every one-fourth hour thereafter. 
(3)  Storage fees: Maximum storage fees shall be set at $25.00 per day. 
(b)  Such rates shall be conspicuously posted in the wrecker service operator's place of business for the attention and information of the general public and for claimants of vehicles under wrecker service operator's care. All billings or statements of charges are to be itemized and will have clearly printed on the reverse side, the rates applicable pursuant to this article so that they may be verified by the claimant. 
(Res. of 8-11-1987; Ord. of 11-14-1995, § 5; Ord. of 07-11-2017(1)) 
Sec. 44-24. - Telephone and radio communication. 
The wrecker service operator will provide, at no cost to the county, a designated telephone number and line to be used exclusively by the county 911 central dispatcher or sheriff's office employee for the purpose of notifying a wrecker service operator whenever such wrecker service operator's services are needed. 
(Res. of 8-11-1987; Ord. of 11-14-1995, § 6; Ord. of 07-11-2017(1)) 
Sec. 44-25. - Minimum drivers. 
The wrecker service operator must submit and have available at all times at least one qualified wrecker operator with a valid driver's license issued by the State of Georgia, or, if the wrecker service maintains a wrecker having a GVW of 26,001 pounds or more, at least one qualified wrecker operator with a valid commercial driver's license (CDL). The wrecker service operator must submit a list of drivers' names, social security numbers, dates of birth, and drivers' license numbers to the county. 
(Res. of 8-11-1987; Ord. of 11-14-1995, § 7; Ord. of 07-11-2017(1)) 
Sec. 44-26. - Wrecker services used by sheriff's department. 
(a)  The county board of commissioners shall compile a list of all wrecker service operators licensed under this article which are qualified to accept calls from the county 911 central dispatcher or sheriff's office employee for the purposes of hauling or storing vehicles as those terms are defined in this article, and the county sheriff's office radio dispatcher shall contact and call and request the services only of those wrecker service operators which have been licensed pursuant to the terms of this article which is for the protection of the general public and in furtherance of its police powers. Any wreckers called by the county 911 central dispatcher or sheriff's office employee shall be required to reach the vehicle to be hauled within 30-minute periods or said dispatcher shall be authorized to call the next wrecker service operator on the list. A wrecker service will not be allowed to drive to the scene in that 30-minute period in a wrecker or other vehicle insufficient to tow the vehicle it was called to, for the purpose of giving their sufficient wrecker time to get there. 
(b)  Only one wrecker service will be dispatched by the county sheriff's department to the scene of an accident. It will be at the discretion of the investigating officer to call for additional help if warranted by the circumstances of the accident; however, the wrecker service initially called from the rotational list shall be entitled to first choice of the wreckage to remove. 
(Res. of 8-11-1987; Ord. of 11-14-1995, § 8; Ord. of 07-11-2017(1)) 
Sec. 44-27. - Solicitation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any employee of the county to solicit towing business of wrecked vehicles for or in behalf of any wrecker operator. 
(b)  The operator of a wrecker shall at all times obey the orders and directions of members of the county sheriff's department. No operator of a wrecker shall drive his vehicle within 50 yards of any vehicle involved in an accident for the purpose of soliciting the tow of any wrecked vehicle unless: 
(1)  Such action is necessary to render first aid or assistance to a motorist or to a passenger of the vehicle involved in a wreck when the wrecker arrives at the scene of an accident first; or 
(2)  The wrecker operator is requested to remove the vehicle or render assistance by a county police officer. 
(Res. of 8-11-1987; Ord. of 11-14-1995, § 9; Ord. of 07-11-2017(1)) 
Sec. 44-28. - Denial, suspension or withdrawal of license. 
(a)  A license or an application for a license under this article may be denied, suspended or revoked only for due cause as defined in subsection (c) of this section. A license may be denied or suspended by the licensing officer as set forth in this article; provided, however, that a license may be revoked only after a hearing before the governing authority of the county upon a prior written notice to the applicant or licensee of the time, place and purpose of such hearing and a statement of the reason why the license is to be revoked. Three days' notice shall be deemed reasonable, but shorter or longer periods of notice shall be authorized as the board of commissioners may deem the circumstances justify. Unless the circumstances otherwise justify, the hearing shall be generally held no later than 45 days after the fully completed application is filed with the licensing officer, or after the licensing officer has suspended a license. If a license is denied by the county manager under this article, the reasons for such denial shall be set forth in writing to the applicant. The applicant shall have 30 days following receipt of notice of denial to appeal the decision of the county manager to the governing authority, which shall review such application de novo at the next regular meeting of the governing authority following receipt of any such appeal, or, at the election of said governing authority, at a special meeting within 45 days following said appeal; provided, however, that any appeal received within ten business days prior to the next regular meeting of the governing authority shall be heard at the second regularly scheduled meeting of said governing authority following receipt of said appeal. If the governing authority affirms the decision of the county manager, then the license shall be denied. If the decision of the county manager is reversed, then the license shall be issued to the applicant. Alternatively, the governing authority may elect to issue the license subject to such reasonable conditions as the governing authority deems appropriate. 
(b)  The county manager may suspend a license where there is evidence of due cause under subsection (c) of this section for revoking the license. Such action by the county manager shall be reported, in writing, to the governing authority. This action shall be reviewed at the next regular meeting of the governing authority, or, at the election of said governing authority, at a special meeting within 30 days following said suspension. If the governing authority affirms the decision of the county manager, then the license shall be permanently revoked. If the decision of the county manager is reversed, then the license shall be returned to the licensee immediately. Alternatively, the governing authority may elect to return the license to the licensee subject to such reasonable conditions as the governing authority deems appropriate. 
(c)  A license or application therefor under this article may be denied, suspended or revoked if one or more of the following exists: 
(1)  The applicant or licensee has failed to obtain any paper, permit, approval, or document required under this article. 
(2)  The applicant or licensee has supplied false information to the county manager or the governing authority. 
(3)  The applicant or licensee has violated any federal, state, or local statute, ordinance, regulation, rule, or law applicable to the towing and recovery services, to include, without limitation, any provision contained in this article. 
(4)  Allowing any condition relating to the towing and recovery services that endangers public health or safety. 
(d)  Unless otherwise determined by the board of commissioners following a hearing as provided herein, any licensee may petition for reinstatement of any license revoked hereunder no sooner than six months from the date of revocation. Such petition shall be submitted on forms provided by the county, and shall first be reviewed by the county manager, who, following a hearing in the matter, shall make a recommendation regarding reinstatement to the board of commissioners. Said recommendation shall be nonbinding, and shall be decided by the board of commissioners following a subsequent hearing in matter. 
(Ord. of 07-11-2017(1))
